This paper reports event-related fMRI in healthy adult humans (n=23, ages 24–34) performing a social-related task (perception of dynamic emotional facial expressions — social communication / perception of others). The human data are analyzed and reported separately from monkey data. The study presents group-level whole-brain random-effects analyses with cluster-wise correction and reports stereotactic coordinates (supplementary table and figures), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (action understanding) in healthy adults (N=19, ages 18–32). The task is social-related (why/how/what observation goals) and uses task-evoked, group-level voxelwise analyses. Although main analyses were restricted to an a priori mask of mirror neuron and mentalizing systems, the manuscript explicitly notes that details about the mask and whole-brain results are provided in the Supplemental Methods, and group-level random-effects analyses were conducted and reported (cluster coordinates/tables and figures). Thus it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social task (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), whole-brain group-level voxelwise results (I5), and acceptability of coordinate/figure reporting (I6).

This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (mean age 22.4, n=16 after exclusions) investigating visual perspective taking — a social-cognitive process (perception/understanding of others). The task is social in nature (self vs. other perspective judgments). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Inconsistent Other > Consistent Other; Consistent Self > Consistent Other) with cluster-level FWE correction and tables of results and coordinates. Whole-brain analyses are explicitly described and attributed to the healthy participant group. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and provides whole-brain activation maps/coordinates.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=21, mean age 24) that uses action observation and execution paradigms addressing mirror-system responses—tasks directly relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’, a social cognition construct. The paper reports group-level voxelwise analyses including a whole-brain analysis (p<0.001 uncorrected) and ROI analyses, with second-level random-effects contrasts and reported peak coordinates, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results. The sample falls within the 18–65 age range and healthy-group results are reported separately. The study is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, nor non-empirical. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing: participants (n=22 healthy adults, mean age 25) underwent task-based fMRI while viewing dynamic social videos designed to evoke interactive vs. observational social cognition. The paper reports group-level random-effects (RFX) whole-brain ANOVA analyses and one-sample t-tests, with voxelwise results presented (ROI small-volume corrections were applied for hypothesis testing, and an exploratory whole-brain analysis revealed early visual (V1) activation). Peak coordinates (MNI) and group-level contrasts are reported for the healthy participant group. Thus the study uses task fMRI of social constructs (I3), includes healthy adult participants (I4), provides group-level voxelwise task-evoked results (I5), and reports coordinates/figures consistent with acceptable whole-brain reporting (I6). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) apply.

This is an fMRI study that directly manipulated social information (trustworthiness judgments) versus nonsocial information during an n-back task. Participants were healthy adults (mean age 22; final imaging N=14), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (2×2 repeated-measures ANOVA) with cluster correction and tables of peak coordinates (Tables 2–4), clearly identifying healthy-group task effects. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for fMRI social-task data, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task activation reporting. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state only, non-healthy-only groups, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception/understanding of others’ pain/empathy) in healthy adult participants (n≈36, mean age ~21). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (pre- and post-priming contrasts of painful vs non-painful stimuli) with thresholding (P<0.05 FDR) and provides coordinates/tables of activations (e.g., MCC/dMPFC, bilateral AI, SII, MTG/STS). Behavioral and imaging results are reported for the healthy sample. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This paper reports original fMRI data using social-related tasks (fame recognition and social closeness judgments), which map onto social perception/understanding of others. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (final N=15 females, mean age 22.33), within the 18–65 range. The authors present group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (random-effects GLM; voxelwise FDR and cluster-corrected thresholds) and report peak coordinates from whole-brain analyses. Results and coordinates are clearly described in text/tables and figures. The study is empirical and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

The study used task-based fMRI to examine perception of face gender, which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ (a social-related construct). The sample consists of healthy adult participants (ages 19–42) with group results reported for the healthy sample. Importantly, the paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxel-wise random-effects analyses (gender-different > gender-same), with cluster-corrected maps and reported activated clusters/coordinates, fulfilling the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. ROI analyses are also present but do not preclude inclusion because whole-brain results are reported. No exclusion criteria apply.

This paper reports an event-related fMRI study of social (interpersonal) conflict processing using a human vs computer social task, directly addressing social-related processing. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (final N=17, mean age 23.5), meeting the age and health requirements. Group-level whole-brain, voxelwise analyses were performed (second-level random-effects factorial model) with reported contrast maps, tables of activations, thresholding details, and figures—satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Results for the healthy participant group are clearly reported (Conflict > No Conflict, interaction contrasts, conjunctions, and covariate analyses). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state only, between-group-only without healthy-group maps, non-adult-only sample, or non-empirical paper) apply. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an fMRI study (whole-brain, voxelwise GLM analyses reported with thresholds and a Table of regions) that examined neural activity during tasks involving understanding actions (Why-How) and generating categories/exemplars. The Why-How task probes social-cognitive processing (construal of others’ actions/intentions) and the paper explicitly discusses recruitment of the mentalizing/default-mode network, meeting the review’s definition of social-related processing. The sample consists of healthy adults (N=24, ages 18–27). Whole-brain group-level contrasts and conjunction analyses are reported and clearly described in text, figures, and tables. Therefore criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 are satisfied.

This is an fMRI experiment of social-related processing (attractiveness comparisons of people) using a task that probes perception/understanding of others. The sample consists of 25 healthy adult women (mean age 23.46, range within 18–65), satisfying the healthy adult sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation results (whole-brain analyses, conjunctions, and ROI checks) with voxelwise and cluster-level thresholds, and reports coordinates/tables and figures in the text. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply. Inclusion criteria met: I3, I4, I5, I6.

Study used task-based fMRI during a social interaction paradigm (modified Cyberball) in healthy adult participants (N=15, mean age 24.1). The paper reports both ROI-based MVPA and an exploratory whole-brain searchlight analysis with group-level, whole-brain corrected results (significant STS coordinates reported), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked group-level maps. Thus it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, and I5; I6 is also satisfied because whole-brain results are reported as MNI coordinates and described in text.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing about groups and individuals) using task-based functional MRI in healthy adult participants (ages 18–27). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain contrasts (e.g., group mental > group physical; member mental > member physical; individual mental > individual physical) with tables of significant regions, corrected thresholds, and figures, satisfying whole-brain evidence reporting. Behavioral and imaging methods, participant characteristics, and univariate and multivariate analyses are fully described for the healthy sample. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study that uses a social, speed-dating paradigm to probe responses to romantic interest/rejection (social affiliation/understanding of others), meeting the social-task requirement. The scanned sample comprises healthy adults (N=38, ages 19–31) with screening for psychiatric diagnoses. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation analyses (SPM8; thresholded maps and tables of coordinates for multiple contrasts) clearly from the healthy/control group. Results are presented in figures and coordinate tables. Therefore it satisfies I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (communicative vs private intentions) in healthy adults. Sample: 23 right-handed healthy adults (mean age ~24), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., CInt > PInt; interaction CInt0° > CInt30°) with stereotaxic coordinates, tables, figures, and statistical thresholds (voxelwise thresholds and FDR-corrected PPI results). Whole-brain results from the healthy participant group are clearly described. Therefore the study satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion criteria for task-based fMRI in healthy adults and reports whole-brain task-evoked maps. Inclusion criteria met: I3, I4, I5, I6.

This is an fMRI study of social regulation (handholding) in a healthy adult sample (N=22; mean age ~23), meeting the age and sample requirements. The task is social/affiliation-related (friend, stranger, alone conditions). The paper reports group-level voxelwise whole-brain analyses using FSL (cluster-wise tests with Z>2.3, p<.05) and lists ROIs/coordinates (Table 1), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=18, mean age 26) that uses task-based fMRI to probe social-related processing (explicit laughter type categorization and implicit bout counting) and reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (CSL>TIC, TIC>CSL, CAT>COU) with thresholds and corrections. Whole-brain results are described in the text, figures, and cluster-level inferences. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult task fMRI and reports whole-brain task-evoked maps.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication (imitation and observation of communicative gestures) in healthy adults (20 analyzed; mean age 24.6). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts and cluster-corrected results with coordinate tables and figures (e.g., IMI>CT conjunction, S>NS contrasts, interaction analyses). Healthy-control results are reported separately and meet voxelwise whole-brain reporting standards. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state-only, non-adult-only samples, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion requirements.

The study reports task-based fMRI during presentation of images of human suffering and emotion-regulation strategies, a social-related paradigm tapping perception/understanding of others and prosocial behavior. Participants were healthy adults (ages 18–45). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses with corrected whole-brain results (e.g., IPC and DLPFC clusters) and describes these maps in the text and supplemental material. Therefore it satisfies I3, I4, I5, and I6. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study is an empirical, task-based fMRI investigation of social-related processing: participants performed a gambling task where outcomes benefitted self, a best friend, or an antagonist, directly probing social-affiliation/other-related processing. The sample comprises healthy adults (N=31, ages 18–26). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (repeated-measures ANOVAs) with tables/coordinates and figures identifying significant clusters (ventral striatum, mPFC, TPJ, precuneus), satisfying the whole-brain reporting requirement. Results are clearly presented for the healthy participant group. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6, and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication/influence in healthy adult participants (mean age ~20.6). The task involved social processing (message encoding/intention to recommend) and used task-based whole-brain voxelwise analyses reported at the group level (whole-brain results with MNI coordinates and thresholding are provided). Thus it meets the review’s neuroimaging and sample requirements and reports whole-brain activation maps rather than ROI- or connectivity-only results.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults investigating recognition of ‘vitality forms’—a social-perceptual construct related to perception and understanding of others. Sample: 19 healthy adults (ages 21–29) meeting the adult age range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation contrasts (what vs baseline, how vs baseline, how vs what) with tables of coordinates and PFWE-corrected results and ROI follow-ups. Thus it provides whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked maps clearly identified as coming from the healthy group. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (theory of mind, emotion, pain attribution) in healthy adults. It reports task-evoked, group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (second-level one-sample t-tests using SnPM, whole-brain maps and tables/figures, MNI normalization) for the healthy control sample (46 female adults, ages 18–31). Analyses include univariate whole-brain contrasts and multivoxel pattern analyses with reported whole-brain results and figures/tables. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study uses task-based fMRI of a social-evaluation paradigm (being watched by a peer), satisfying the social-related fMRI requirement. The sample includes healthy adult participants (ages up to 22.9 years), so healthy adults (18–65) are present in the dataset, and all participants are healthy. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (mixed-model, whole-brain ANOVAs) with corrected cluster results (e.g., MPFC activation and MPFC–striatum coupling) reported in the text and supplemental materials. Results are not limited to ROI- or connectivity-only analyses and are presented as whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps. Caveat: analyses are conducted across a mixed-age healthy sample rather than an adult-only group; however, inclusion criteria require at least one group of healthy adult participants and whole-brain maps from the healthy group, which are met. Therefore, include.

This is an fMRI study that directly investigates perception of nonverbal dyadic social interactions (social communication) using a task in which healthy adult participants (n=21, ages 23–33) rated naturalness while undergoing fMRI. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., contingent vs. mirrored, rigid vs. smooth) analyzed with SPM8 and reports cluster-level corrected results and MNI coordinates in tables and figures. Thus it provides whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social impression formation (social cognition) in healthy adults. The task is social (impression formation of real people met in person), and the sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=19, mean age 19.1). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (functional localizer: form impression > remember order) with cluster-corrected results and tables of coordinates/cluster sizes (Tables 1 and 2), and describes whole-brain coverage and cluster correction procedures (AFNI alphasim). Whole-brain results are clearly attributed to the healthy participant group. Therefore the study satisfies inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (passive viewing of biological motion/point-light displays) that directly probes social perception. The sample includes a healthy adult group (n=48; ages 20–35) analyzed separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., biological > scrambled; Sex × Condition ANOVA) with thresholding and cluster correction, presented in figures and tables. Results for the healthy adult group are clearly described. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 19–28) that uses task-based paradigms probing social-related processing (eye-gaze detection, self-propelling motion, and implicit mental inference). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses are reported (contrasts such as E–O and S–X; second-level one-sample t-tests and voxelwise regression analyses), with results presented in figures and tables. The paper therefore meets all required inclusion criteria for the review and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social cognition task (third-party punishment/attribution of moral responsibility), satisfying the review’s social-related task requirement. The sample comprises 26 healthy adults (mean age 26 ± 5.7), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (random-effects GLM, mixed ANOVA) and reports Talairach coordinates and statistical thresholds (q(FDR)<0.05) for activations (e.g., right TPJ, right anterior insula), fulfilling whole-brain reporting requirements. Results are reported for the healthy sample and not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria appear to be violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI using social stimuli (traffic awareness videos eliciting socio-cognitive processing), includes healthy adult participants (two groups of right-handed male drivers, ages 19–30), and presents group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (CV vs NV) with whole-brain analyses reported for each group and in the text/figures. Thus it meets social-related fMRI task requirement, healthy adult sample, and the presence of whole-brain group-level activation maps/results (reported in figures and text).

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-relevant task (passive viewing of faces versus objects), which targets social perception/understanding of others. The study includes a healthy adult group (N=21 adults, ages 18–37) reported separately within the sample. It reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (faces>objects contrasts and age-regression whole-brain results) with coordinates and tables (Table 3) and figures of whole-brain effects, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Results are clearly from healthy participants (no patient-only sample). Therefore the paper meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study that uses a social-related task (attribute framing of personal traits from self/other perspectives), satisfying the social processing requirement. The sample consists of healthy adults aged 19–41 (N=21 initially, with 2 exclusions), meeting the age and healthy-sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation analyses (GLM contrasts, voxel-wise thresholds, cluster-corrected results) with coordinates and figures for multiple contrasts (e.g., positive vs negative frame, frame-inconsistent vs frame-consistent), fulfilling whole-brain reporting requirements. Results are presented for the healthy participant group (not restricted to a subgroup). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are met. Therefore the study should be included.

The study reports task-based fMRI during social evaluation (explicit approachability judgments of faces vs implicit sex judgment), directly addressing social-related processing. It describes group-level task contrasts showing activations (e.g., left amygdala, medial/middle/inferior frontal gyri) and BOLD correlations with trait anxiety, which indicates whole-brain task-evoked analyses were performed and reported. The sample is described as participants (healthy group) with trait anxiety measured, implying a healthy adult cohort. Thus it meets inclusion: I3 (fMRI social task), I4 (healthy adult participants reported), I5 (group-level whole-brain task activations reported), and I6 (results described in text/figures). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, non-empirical) appear to apply based on the provided content.

This paper reports multiple task-based fMRI experiments in healthy adult participants using a social-affective paradigm (empathic judgments of others) and provides group-level voxelwise results. fMRI Experiment 1 performed whole-brain random-effects analyses (exploratory whole-brain thresholded maps) and fMRI Experiment 2 used independent localizers and reports group-level activation coordinates (with small-volume correction) and also conducted whole-brain analyses. Sample consists of healthy adult (female undergraduate) participants reported separately. Results are reported as coordinates, figures, and group-level contrasts related to social processing. Therefore it meets the review's fMRI, healthy adult sample, whole-brain task-evoked map, and reporting criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study that directly investigates social-related processing using a Dynamic Social Gesture task (meets I3). The sample comprises 20 healthy young adults (mean age 21.4; age range 16.9–25.7) — the sample includes adults within the 18–65 range and reports healthy-group results (meets I4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (TFCE with permutation testing) and presents activations in figures and tables/ supplementary material (meets I5 and I6). The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not solely a between-group contrast, and is empirical fMRI work in healthy adults, so no exclusion criteria apply.

This peer-reviewed study used task-based functional MRI during social interactions (collaborative, individual, competitive) involving healthy adult participants (N=32; ages 18–39). It reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM GLM results, clusterwise FWE-corrected maps and tables of activations) for parametric modulators including personal utility, collaboration, competition, and social position. Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control sample and not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it satisfies the review’s requirements for an fMRI social-processing task in healthy adults with whole-brain task activation maps.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (mean age 26) who performed social-judgment tasks (assessment of ambiguous social interactions) following tactile priming. Behavioral task assesses social coordination, a social-cognition construct. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (ANOVA and post-hoc t-tests) with results reported at FDR-corrected thresholds, figures of statistical maps, and tables of activation peaks. Sample is within 18–65 and healthy; whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy group are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria are met.

This paper reports a structural MRI (voxel-based morphometry) study relating grey matter volume to proneness to moral sentiments in healthy adults. It does not present functional MRI task activation results or a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical map from healthy participants. A small subgroup previously participated in an earlier fMRI study, and the authors used SSC-BOLD responses from that prior work as a covariate in exploratory analyses, but this manuscript itself does not report healthy-group whole-brain fMRI activation maps or coordinates. Therefore it fails inclusion criteria I3 and I5 and must be excluded from a meta-analysis of fMRI task activations. Note: the sample consists of healthy adults (meets I4) but this does not salvage lack of fMRI whole-brain results.

The study reports fMRI data collected during a live verbal social interaction task (speech/listening/imagination) involving healthy adult participants (22 women, mean age ~27). Group-level, whole-brain voxel-wise second-level analyses (one-tailed t-tests) are reported for talking, listening and imagining, with cluster-thresholding and results presented in text/figures/supplementary tables. The task is clearly social communication-related. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for task relevance, healthy adult sample, and provision of whole-brain task-evoked maps.

This is an fMRI study that explicitly examines social-related processing (trustworthiness and attractiveness judgments) using vocal stimuli, fulfilling the review topic. Sample: 44 healthy adults aged 21–60, meeting the healthy adult age range. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (SPM8), provides MNI coordinates, cluster-level FWE-corrected results, conjunctions and tables/figures of activations clearly from the healthy group. Whole-brain results are presented in text, tables and figures. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical, task-based fMRI study of social communication/empathy using naturalistic videos (addresses social communication/empathy constructs). The sample comprises 27 healthy adults (mean age 34), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM results and multiple voxelwise contrasts (e.g., E > N, channel-specific contrasts and conjunctions) presented as figures and coordinate-based findings. Although the paper also presents effective connectivity (DCM), it clearly provides healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps, satisfying the review requirements. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (empathy, Theory of Mind, self–other differentiation) using task-based BOLD imaging in healthy adult participants (15 right-handed males aged 18–40). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level random-effects analyses with voxelwise contrasts, cluster thresholds, peak coordinates, conjunctions, and figures/tables describing healthy-group task effects (sad vs neutral; condition contrasts). Thus it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult samples, or non-empirical) are violated.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social decision-making paradigm (one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma) directly probing social cognition and trust, addressing the review objective. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (mean age 24.6, range consistent with 18–65) with group-level analyses reported for the healthy sample. The authors report whole-brain, voxelwise GLM results (group contrasts, interaction effects) with cluster-size correction and provide tables/figures and peak coordinates, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. Results for the healthy groups (prosocial vs proself) are clearly described. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This publication is a review article (non-empirical) and does not report original fMRI data, participant samples, methods, or any group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from healthy adults. It therefore does not meet the requirement for original fMRI results in healthy adults and should be excluded.

This study employed task-based fMRI probing social-related processing (familiar/partner faces) relevant to affiliation/attachment and perception/understanding of others. It includes a healthy control group (n=13, mean age 64.5) reported separately from the patient, and presents group-level whole-brain voxelwise contrasts for the control group (partner > unfamiliar; FWE-corrected results and coordinates are reported). Results are described in figures/tables and whole-brain analyses are clearly attributed to the healthy/control group. The only minor uncertainty is that exact age ranges for controls are not listed (mean 64.5 ±5.7 suggests some participants may approach or slightly exceed 65), hence a confidence <1.0. Overall, the paper meets the review’s requirements for inclusion.

This is an empirical fMRI study using the Ultimatum Game (a social decision-making task) and reports whole-brain, group-level task contrasts. The sample includes a healthy adult group (young adults age 19–28) with results for that group reported separately. The paper provides voxelwise contrasts (unfair–fair) and group-level statistical maps/tables for the adult group. Reporting of whole-brain results is in figures/tables and described in text. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This paper reports an fMRI study of social interaction (free online imitation), meeting the review objective. Participants were healthy adults (23 right-handed females, age 18–30). Group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked activation contrasts are reported (e.g., imitating vs rest, being imitated vs rest, observation vs rest) with correction for multiple comparisons (FWE p<0.05) and coordinates/tables provided. The study therefore provides whole-brain evidence for the healthy group rather than only ROI or connectivity-only results (although PPI is also reported). All inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This task-based fMRI study investigates processing of natural interpersonal touch (touch delivered by another person), which is a social-related stimulus (social communication/affiliation). Participants were healthy adults (N=8, ages 22–39). The authors report group-level, whole-brain voxelwise spatial maps derived from group ICA (thresholded IC maps shown and described) and present task-evoked component time courses demonstrating stimulus dependence; these constitute group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps. Although analyses used ICA rather than a standard GLM contrast, the reported group spatial maps and stimulus-related effects satisfy the requirement for whole-brain task activation evidence. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, and reports healthy-group results explicitly. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

The paper reports task-based fMRI during a faces-versus-houses task (socially relevant face perception), in a healthy adult sample (N=57 total; fMRI subset N=22; mean age ~18.9). The authors performed group-level, whole-brain second-level GLM analyses and report significant whole-brain activations and clusters (bilateral fusiform gyrus; suprathreshold voxel counts and cluster tables/figures), satisfying the requirement for healthy-group voxelwise task-evoked maps. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, pediatric-only, or non-empirical) are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study that includes a social-related task (social distance trials using participants' friends and acquaintances) and analyzes healthy adult participants (n=15, ages 20–28). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses: information-based searchlight MVPA and representational similarity analyses produced statistical maps and significant clusters (e.g., right IPL) tested across participants (FDR-corrected). These constitute whole-brain task-evoked group results clearly from the healthy sample. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

Although the study used fMRI with a social-related task (social closeness judgments of friends vs unfamiliar faces) and included healthy adult participants (ages 19–30), the reported fMRI results are restricted to ROI-based analyses (ROIs derived from VBM peaks) rather than providing any group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy/control group. The paper reports VBM (structural) whole-brain/ROI results but the task fMRI findings are extracted beta weights from predefined ROIs and SVCs; no unmasked whole-brain task activation maps or voxelwise contrasts for the healthy group are presented. This violates the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results (I5) and thus meets exclusion criterion E2.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (direct self, direct other, reflected self; social/academic/physical domains), satisfying the social-related task requirement. It includes a healthy adult group (N=19, ages 22–31) analyzed and reported separately from the adolescent group. Whole-brain, voxelwise group-level analyses were conducted (2×4×3 whole-brain ANOVA) with multiple-comparison correction (AlphaSim) and significant clusters reported with coordinates (e.g., bilateral ventral striatum), and results are described in text, figures, and supplementary materials. Thus, whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps/contrasts are available. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult-only sample, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study investigating neural responses to witnessing emergencies (bystander effect) using task-evoked BOLD contrasts. Participants were healthy adults (ages 18–27). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects GLM, parametric and contrast maps) with results presented in tables and figures. The task is a social-related paradigm probing perception/understanding of others and action preparation in a bystander context. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only groups, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion requirements for the review objective.

This is an fMRI study of social cognitive processing (causal attribution/mentalizing) in a healthy adult sample (N=20; ages 18–41). The task is social (attributing causes to self, other, situation) and clearly fits the review’s social-related constructs. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (ANOVA, contrasts, conjunction), including whole-brain results and FWE-corrected clusters (Table 1, figures, and text), clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Results are reported as coordinates and statistical maps/contrasts. Therefore it satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

This study reports an fMRI experiment that directly probes social attribution of awareness (a social-cognition task) in a sample of healthy adult participants (n=50, ages 18–49). Group-level, whole-brain task-evoked results are reported (H trials − E trials contrast) with corrected statistical thresholds, cluster-size correction, figures, and Talairach coordinates (Table 1). The healthy/control group results are clearly presented and not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=26, age range within 18–65) using social tasks (Cyberball exclusion and a modified Dictator Game) that probe affiliation, social evaluation, and perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., exclusion no ball > inclusion ball; Excluders > Includers; excluders equality > includers equality) with peak coordinates, figures, and tables of significant clusters (and mentions Supplementary Table S1), meeting the requirement for whole-brain evidence. Results are reported for the healthy participant group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of anticipatory interpersonal touch (a clearly social-related task) in healthy adult participants (N=16, ages 20–34). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxel-wise task contrasts (e.g., Target, Modality, Target×Modality interactions) with cluster-level correction, figures, and a table of coordinates; analyses include conjunctions and voxel-wise results within a tactile localizer mask. Results for the healthy/control group are reported directly (not limited to a subgroup). The study is empirical and not ROI-only, resting-state, or between-group-only. Therefore it meets the review inclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of self-referential/social cognition (conceptual vs agentic self/other recollection), conducted in healthy adult participants (age range 19–29). The paper reports group-level voxelwise task-evoked activation contrasts with coordinate tables and whole-brain results (including FWE-corrected whole-brain clusters and conjunction analyses), clearly from the healthy participant sample. Thus it satisfies the meta-analysis requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (intergroup competition, self-referential moral processing) in healthy adult participants (Mage=23.1, N=21). The paper reports group-level whole-brain random-effects analyses with corrected thresholds and tables/coordinates (whole-brain results and clusters are reported), not ROI-only. The task is social in nature (perception/understanding of self and intergroup relations). Thus it meets inclusion for use of fMRI during a social-related task, healthy adult sample, and reporting of whole-brain group-level task activation maps (coordinates/tables). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI study of facial color processing during face viewing, a social-perception/social-communication task. It tested 25 healthy adult participants (mean age 25.2), and reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (natural-colored face vs natural-colored scrambled image) with coordinates and group-level maps. Whole-brain results are clearly described in the text and figures (and Table 1), satisfying the requirement for group-level voxelwise activation maps. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy age group, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI study that directly investigates social feedback processing (a social-related task) in healthy adult participants (German and Chinese adults). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation results (whole-brain FWE-corrected clusters and tables of activations) for the healthy groups, including contrasts and parametric modulation analyses. Results are clearly attributed to the healthy/control groups. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for task relevance, sample, and whole-brain reporting.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (interactive emotional alignment) in healthy adults. The task is explicitly social (ratings communicated between interaction partners) and uses task-evoked BOLD fMRI. The sample includes healthy adults (n=20 scanned, mean age 23.9), and results are reported at the group level with whole-brain voxelwise analyses (clusterwise FWE-corrected threshold, tables/figures with coordinates). The paper reports whole-brain group contrasts and coordinates (Tables/Figures) clearly attributed to the healthy participant group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all required inclusion criteria for the review.

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (viewing realistic first-person social interaction videos) in a healthy adult sample (n=20 males, mean age 24.6). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses are reported (FDR-corrected thresholds) with peak coordinates and tables/figures, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. Behavioral and imaging results are clearly described for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults: participants (N=10, males aged 22–32) viewed dyadic point-light displays depicting social interactions while performing an unrelated task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (atypical > typical and related contrasts) with cluster-size correction, tables/figures of peak coordinates, and ROI/ connectivity follow-ups. It thus provides healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps for a social cognition paradigm. Inclusion criteria satisfied: I3 (fMRI during social-related task), I4 (healthy adult sample reported separately), I5 (group-level whole-brain voxelwise task maps), I6 (results in tables/figures/text). No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (imagined triadic interactions vs self/other/control), conducted in healthy adult participants (n=19, ages 18–35). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., triad > iron; triad > (self & other)) with whole-brain FWE-corrected thresholds and reports peak coordinates/tables and figures. Results for the healthy control group are clearly reported and not limited to ROI- or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for task relevance, sample, and whole-brain reporting.

Although this is an fMRI study of a social task (Ultimatum Game) in healthy adult participants and reports group-level contrasts, the second-level analyses were performed within a restricted mask comprising 16 bilateral ROIs (wfu_pickatlas). The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain voxelwise group-level task activation map; results are effectively ROI-restricted. This meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, and acceptable reporting format I6, but violates the requirement for whole-brain group-level results (exclusion criterion E2: ROI-only analyses). Therefore the study should be excluded from the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study using an ecologically valid social interaction task (adapted Taylor Aggression Paradigm) presenting opponents' facial expressions; sample comprises healthy adult males (32 included in analyses, mean age 23.3); the paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (angry > neutral) with cluster-wise FWE correction and presents tables/figures of whole-brain results. Thus it satisfies fMRI social processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults. It used task-based fMRI during a social/competitive matching-pennies paradigm involving human and non-human agents (social-related processing/mentalizing). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=16, ages 18–25). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise GLM group-level random-effects analyses with voxelwise thresholding (p<.001) and cluster-level FWE correction across the whole brain; results are presented in figures and tables with coordinates. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (task-based fMRI of social processing, healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level voxelwise results, and appropriately reported maps/tables). No exclusion criteria apply.

This fMRI study investigates impression formation (perception and understanding of others), uses a task-based fMRI paradigm in healthy adult participants (20 males, ages 19–31), and reports both ROI and an exploratory whole-brain voxelwise analysis (whole-brain voxelwise ANOVA with results shown in table/figures). Thus it meets the review objective and reports group-level whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy sample.

This is an fMRI study of theory-of-mind/false-belief processing in healthy adults (mean age 22.7) using task-based fMRI while participants watched Sally–Anne movies (social-related task). Group-level, whole-brain random-effects contrasts are reported (belief > photo/map; implicit false- > true-belief) with SPMs and peak coordinates. Results for the healthy adult sample are presented separately. Thus all inclusion criteria (I3, I4, I5, I6) are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study reports an fMRI experiment examining interpersonal synchrony and affiliative processing (a social-related task), with behavioral and neuroimaging results. The sample includes healthy adult participants (total N=100 across studies; neuroimaging subgroup reported separately). The manuscript describes involvement of brain areas implicated in social cognition (i.e., task-evoked activation), indicating group-level whole-brain task contrasts/activation maps (reported as regional activations in the neuroimaging study), consistent with whole-brain voxelwise reporting (and acceptable coordinate/table reporting per I6). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, non-empirical) are apparent. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an fMRI task study probing socio-emotional processing (empathy induction) using campaign vs. control videos — a clear social-related task. Participants were healthy adults (20 right-handed male volunteers, ages 20–28). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (CV>NV contrast) with FWE-corrected results and peak coordinates used as ROIs; effects are described in text/tables/figures. Thus it meets the review’s task, sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply.

This study uses task-based fMRI to investigate cross-modal person recognition (voice→face), which is a social perception/understanding-of-others task. The sample is healthy adults (n=16, ages 20–31). The authors performed voxelwise, group-level random-effects analyses in SPM (second-level t-statistics at each voxel) and report voxel coordinates and statistical contrasts (identity and physical-distance contrasts), with results presented as coordinate peaks and corrected p-values (FWE, ROI and some whole-brain references). Whole-brain, voxelwise contrasts and coordinate tables are described in the text and figures for the healthy participant group. Therefore the paper meets the fMRI social-task, healthy adult sample, and reporting of group-level voxelwise results criteria (I3, I4, I5, I6).

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of biological motion/social stimuli) in healthy adult participants (final N=26; ages 18–39). The paper reports both ROI analyses and whole-brain, voxelwise analyses: a whole-brain analysis of biological-motion selectivity and social-network measures yielded a significant cluster in the right pSTS (reported in text and supplemental Figure S1) with correction for multiple comparisons. Whole-brain results are clearly described for the healthy group. Therefore all relevant inclusion criteria are met.

This fMRI study used a social-related task (explicit labeling of others’ brief emotional facial expressions), scanned healthy adult participants (N=50, ages 18–29), and reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked group-level contrasts and regression results (with cluster-level FWE correction) clearly identified for the healthy sample. Whole-brain results are reported in tables/figures and described in the text. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apply.

This fMRI study directly investigates social-related processing (social sharing of emotions/affiliation) using a task manipulating shared vs unshared viewing (meets I3). Sample comprises healthy adult participants aged 20–33 with fMRI data reported for n=26 (meets I4). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses and whole-brain corrected activations (e.g., DLPFC and precuneus) in addition to ROI results, and describes voxelwise contrasts for the healthy sample (meets I5 and I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social communication in healthy adult participants (female, age 19–28). The task manipulates perceived sender (friend vs computer) during text-message reception, engaging social cognition/mentalizing. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (univariate contrasts and searchlight MVPA/MVCA) with cluster-corrected statistical maps and tables of activated clusters, clearly for the healthy/control group. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This study uses fMRI while participants engaged in a social task (repeated pairwise public good game) examining formation of social ties and prosocial decisions. The sample comprises healthy adults (25 scanned participants, mean age ~22.6), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLM, cluster-wise FWE correction) with MNI coordinates and tables/figures of results. Whole-brain healthy-group effects are clearly described. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of communicative interaction (social communication) in healthy adult participants (54 right-handed males, ages 18–27). The task probes social-related processing (establishment of mutual understanding) and uses task-evoked fMRI with whole-brain group-level analyses (reported contrasts, parametric modulations, and cluster-level inference), including anatomical localization and coherence analyses. Whole-brain results are described in the main text and figures (with supplementary materials), satisfying reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of joint attention (social communication/understanding of others) in healthy adults (final N=13; mean age ~24.9). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (contrasts, conjunctions) with FDR-corrected thresholds and tables/figures of coordinates and statistical maps, clearly from the healthy/control group. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review (social fMRI task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain group results reported, and acceptable reporting via tables/figures).

The paper is a short conference abstract that describes dyadic fMRI and network synchronizations but does not report essential information required by the review. There is no information on participant sample characteristics (age range, number of healthy adults), and no presentation of group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for a healthy adult group. The abstract appears focused on methodological development and connectivity/synchronization analyses rather than reporting unmasked whole-brain task activation results. Therefore it does not meet the review's requirements for whole-brain healthy-group task activation reporting.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (feeling addressed) in healthy adults (N=37, mean age 25). The task is social-related (addressment judgments). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation analyses (SPM8) with main effects, conjunctions, interaction contrasts and peak coordinates; whole-brain correction/cluster thresholds are described. Healthy participant results are reported separately. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (perceiving person interactions), involving a social-related task (sex-categorization while viewing congruent/incongruent person dyads), conducted in healthy adult participants (n=12, ages 21–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain GLM analyses and exploratory whole-brain contrasts (voxelwise p<.001, cluster-based p<.05) with tables of peak coordinates and figures, clearly attributable to the healthy/control group. Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria for task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults and reports whole-brain results.

This is an fMRI study of emotional crowd perception—a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). The sample comprises 16 healthy adult participants (ages 19–27) with results reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects ANOVA results, cluster-corrected voxelwise maps, peak coordinates, tables and figures detailing main effects and interactions, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Reporting of whole-brain activation maps is explicit in text, tables, and figures. The study is empirical and does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or patient-group contrasts. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (deception, theory-of-mind in strategic interaction) using a sender–receiver interactive task (meets social-related task). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=34, age range 21–32) with results reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., simple deception vs. truth, sophisticated deception vs. truth, parametric analyses) with Bayesian second-level probability maps and tables of coordinates/activations and figures, satisfying whole-brain reporting. There is no evidence of ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical study issues. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (prediction of others' behavior framed as desires vs. rules) in healthy adult participants (N=18, ages 18–44). The paper reports task-evoked, group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (second-level flexible factorial models, cluster- and voxel-level correction, tables/coordinates and figures), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and participants are within the 18–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study using dyadic fMRI during a social task (eye contact), with healthy adult participants (19 pairs; ages 18–33). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain GLM analyses and paired t-tests, provides activation maps, cluster results, MNI coordinates, and atlas-based labeling (i.e., whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy group). Thus it meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only without task maps, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) apply.

This article is a theoretical/review paper discussing explanations for mirror-touch synesthesia and does not report original empirical fMRI data or methods/results from healthy adult participants. The abstract indicates conceptual/theoretical discussion and cites existing fMRI evidence but provides no whole-brain, group-level task-evoked maps from a healthy control group, nor any reported task-based fMRI methods/results. Therefore it meets exclusion criterion E6 (non-empirical paper without original fMRI data).

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social attribution (why/how task) in healthy adults that directly addresses social-related processing. Sample: healthy adults aged 21–46 (N=19), satisfying the age and healthy-sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation analyses (conjunctions, interaction contrasts, cluster-corrected whole-brain maps and tables/figures) clearly identified as coming from the healthy group. Whole-brain results are reported in tables and figures. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state only, non-empirical, or out-of-range age samples) apply. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an fMRI study of social-affective processing (mimicry, affiliation/appeasement) in healthy adults using a task manipulating emotion and group membership, satisfying the review topic. Sample: healthy adult participants (N=41 for fMRI analyses; ages reported, within 18–65). Whole-brain, group-level task activation contrasts are reported (e.g., Incongruent>Congruent and masked contrasts for Happy vs Angry, Out-group vs In-group) with cluster-level correction and tables of peak coordinates (Tables 2–4) and detailed methods for SPM analysis. Results are reported for the healthy/control group (no exclusive patient group). Whole-brain results are clearly described in text, tables, and figures. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 and does not violate exclusion criteria (no ROI-only, resting-state-only, or non-empirical limitations).

This study reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (social incentive delay with social reward), includes a healthy adult sample (N=63, ages ~20–36) and reports group-level whole-brain task activation results (whole-brain and ROI FWE-corrected contrasts, tables/figures described). Whole-brain contrasts for anticipation and outcome (e.g., reward>neutral; social>monetary) are presented and clearly come from the healthy/control group. Therefore it satisfies the review inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The study is an fMRI investigation of social working memory (a social-related task: maintaining/manipulating others’ traits/perspectives) conducted in healthy adult participants (N=25, mean age 21.6). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (conjunction and contrasts of parametric modulation by load; cluster and voxelwise thresholds are specified) with tables and figures documenting significant clusters (e.g., Tables 1–2, Figures 4–5). Results are reported for the healthy/control sample (no reliance on restricted subgroups), and whole-brain results are described in text, tables, and figures. Therefore all inclusion criteria for the review are satisfied.

This is an fMRI experiment with healthy adult participants (mean age 24.6) using a social task (observed eye contact and gaze-following). The manuscript reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts with statistical thresholds and coordinate tables/figures (e.g., EC > AG, Cong > Incong, interaction contrasts), clearly from the healthy sample. Thus it satisfies the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI activation in healthy adults and meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (20 participants, ages 19–31) that includes multiple social-task contrasts (ToM, faces, biological motion, voices, language). However, although first-level whole-brain GLMs were computed, the group-level voxelwise analyses reported in the paper were restricted to a bilateral STS mask (i.e., ROI-constrained second-level analyses). The paper does not present an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. Therefore it fails inclusion criterion I5 (group-level whole-brain task-evoked map) and falls under exclusion criterion E2 (studies reporting only ROI-masked results with no whole-brain results).

This is an fMRI study of action understanding that examines mentalizing and abstraction (Why/How task), which falls squarely under social-related processing (perception/understanding of others and mental states). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=17 analyzed; ages 21–46), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (contrasts, cluster-level FWE correction) and whole-brain results/tables/figures (supplementary tables and NeuroVault images are referenced), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only groups, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social/emotional face processing in healthy adults (N=30, mean age 24.2). The task is social-related (gender identification of angry and happy faces vs neutral shapes). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (FWE-corrected whole-brain and ROI analyses are described; main effects of stimulus type and interaction contrasts are reported and supplemented with tables/figures), with results clearly identified for the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results are described in text and supplementary tables. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study is an fMRI investigation of mentalizing (a social-cognition task related to attachment) in a large sample of healthy adult participants (n=164). The paper reports task-evoked neural activations across the mentalizing network (e.g., precuneus, cingulate, TPJ, IFG, amygdala), indicating whole-brain group-level effects rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Thus it meets the social-related task requirement, includes a healthy adult group, and provides whole-brain task activation results (reported in text/figures/tables). No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study investigating neural correlates of the urge to imitate during an observation/imitation task, which pertains to social-related processing (perception/understanding of others; social communication). The sample comprises 37 healthy adult participants (age range 18–25), satisfying the healthy adult sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (parametric modulation contrasts for Urge, Familiarity, Difficulty, Rhythm) with reported statistical thresholds and cluster-level correction; coordinates and activation maps are described. PPI connectivity is also reported but does not replace the whole-brain task activations. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants within 18–65, empirical fMRI data).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults that used a social-related task (viewing social vs. non-social scenes) and reports group-level, whole-brain task activation maps (social>non-social; FDR-corrected, p<0.05) shown in figures and Table 1. The sample consists of healthy adults aged 18–21 (n=33) with results reported for the healthy group. Whole-brain results are clearly described in the text and figures, satisfying the requirement that qualifying results be available at the group level. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and not a non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

The study reports an fMRI experiment involving social-related processing (social reputation), meeting the review topic. The sample consists of 28 healthy young adult participants (14 male, 14 female; ages 20–24), satisfying the healthy adult sample criterion. The paper presents whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked activation analyses (thresholds, cluster-level FWE correction, peak voxels in MNI coordinates, and a results table), clearly identified as group-level results from the healthy/control sample. Whole-brain results are reported in text, figures, and a table of activations. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

The paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (three experiments, N=25, N=65, N=178; Experiment 2 mean age 40.9) using a social cognition paradigm (EmpaToM) probing empathy and Theory of Mind, addressing social-related processing. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts are reported (e.g., empathy contrast, ToM contrast) with tables of activation peaks and figures; second-level one-sample t-tests and FWE-corrected thresholds are described. Behavioral and imaging results for the healthy/control samples are reported separately. Thus the study meets the meta-analysis requirements for task-based fMRI in healthy adults with whole-brain task activation maps and coordinate tables.

This is an fMRI study of social gaze-following (a social-related task examining responses to in-group vs. out-group political faces), conducted in healthy adult participants (ages 18–36). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation contrasts (e.g., incongruent > congruent) with cluster-level correction and provides tables and figures describing activated clusters across the brain (dorsal and ventral fronto-parietal networks, FEF, parietal, occipital regions). Results are reported for the healthy/control sample (no clinical groups). Thus it satisfies the review inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using a social Theory-of-Mind task (animated interacting shapes), reporting task-evoked, group-level whole-brain contrasts (ToM > Random, ToM > Baseline) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction. The sample consists of healthy adult participants with ages 24–64 (within 18–65). Whole-brain results are described in the text and reported with coordinates/figures. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although this fMRI study used a healthy adult sample (N=46, ages 18–45) and reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps (HA− > NTR) and coordinates, the experimental paradigm targets general emotional (negative) picture processing (IAPS) rather than an explicit social-related task (e.g., affiliation/attachment, social communication, mentalizing, or explicit perception/understanding of others). The manuscript focuses on emotion reactivity and fronto-limbic connectivity; while dmPFC has roles in social cognition, the task did not explicitly probe social processes. Therefore it fails inclusion criterion I3 (social-related task), and must be excluded despite meeting other inclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=30, ages 18–35) using an empathy-for-pain paradigm with experimentally induced (minimal) groups, which is a social cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Whole-brain, voxelwise group-level analyses are reported (SPM8 repeated-measures ANOVA; main effects and interactions reported with FWE-corrected and uncorrected thresholds and referenced Tables of results), providing unmasked healthy-group task activation maps. Thus it meets the meta-analysis objective and all required inclusion criteria (I3, I4, I5, I6) and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (all male, mean age 23.6) using a social task (viewing dyadic violent interactions) with an orthogonal behavioral task. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., all conditions vs baseline; focus on aggressor vs victim) with statistical maps and cluster-correction details, and includes figures/tables of whole-brain results and connectivity analyses. Thus it meets all required inclusion criteria for the review (fMRI social task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level results clearly reported). No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=26, ages 19–26) that uses a task contrasting social vs non-social literary passages, directly addressing social cognition/theory-of-mind. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects contrasts (Social>Non-social and Vivid>Abstract) with cluster-level corrected results and peak coordinates (Table 1, figures), satisfying whole-brain reporting. Behavioral ToM measures are included and brain–behavior mediation is reported. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria for task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study that directly examines social-related processing (implicit social stimulus processing) in healthy adults. The sample comprises 28 healthy right-handed adults aged 30–50 (within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical analyses (ANOVA across the 28 subjects), conjunction and direct contrasts, thresholded and reported with cluster sizes and MNI coordinates, and figures/tables of results. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a social exclusion (Cyberball) task—clearly a social-related paradigm. The sample comprises healthy adult university students (unmarried, within adult age range). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task contrasts (exclusion vs inclusion) across all participants (see whole-brain analyses, Table 3 and figures) and provides coordinate tables and figures of these maps. Thus it meets the requirements for task-based fMRI in healthy adults with whole-brain results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy age groups, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (racial in-/out-group disgust face viewing) in healthy adults that reports group-level whole-brain task effects. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (mean age ~21, N=26 analyzed). The paper reports whole-brain voxelwise GLM results (group-level interaction contrast and accompanying tables/figures with peak coordinates and corrected thresholds) and complementary PPI connectivity analyses. Whole-brain results are clearly described and reported (figures/tables), satisfying reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy or out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This paper reports an fMRI study using a social-content valence classification task (agency vs. communion), satisfying the review’s focus on social-related processing. Sample: 42 healthy adult participants (ages 18–25), meeting the adult healthy sample requirement. Whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses were conducted using SPM8 with AlphaSim correction; conjunction and contrast maps (agency vs. fixation, communion vs. fixation, and direct contrasts) are reported and described (tables/figures of coordinates referenced). Thus the study provides qualifying whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state-only, between-group-only contrasts, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are met. Therefore I include the study.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social communication (speech act comprehension) in healthy adults. The sample comprises 18 healthy participants aged 18–41. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses with FDR-corrected contrasts (e.g., Request > Naming) and describes whole-brain results in the text and figures; ROI/SVC analyses are supplementary but do not replace whole-brain reporting. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked results (I3, I4, I5, I6). No exclusion criteria were triggered.

This is a task-based fMRI hyperscanning study of joint attention and mutual gaze (social interaction, social communication/perception). Participants: healthy adult volunteers (ages reported, n provided). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise results (tables of coordinates, cluster-level FWE-corrected results, figures) clearly from the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results are described in text and tables. Therefore it satisfies the meta-analysis requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of dynamic social versus nonsocial gesture processing in a sample of healthy young adults (mean age 21.4) using the DSG task, addressing social-related processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation results (cluster-corrected maps and tables of coordinates) for the healthy participant group. Although the reported age range includes one participant at 16.9 years, the sample is described and analyzed as a healthy young adult group and group-level whole-brain results are clearly reported. Therefore it satisfies the review’s inclusion requirements.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (effortful control of interpersonal trust/distrust) in healthy adult participants (n=59–60, mean age ~20, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation contrasts (e.g., trust > age, distrust > age, and combined contrasts) with family-wise error correction and provides tables/figures and MNI coordinates. Whole-brain results and coordinates are clearly reported in the text/tables/figures, and ROI analyses are supplementary but do not replace whole-brain results. Therefore the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis (I3, I4, I5, I6) and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an original fMRI study of social processing (face-viewing within real-world social networks) in healthy adult participants (n=26; mean age 28.7). The task is social (sociometric popularity, person-judgment, face viewing), satisfying I3. Participants are healthy adults within 18–65, satisfying I4. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, random-effects parametric analyses and provides thresholded clusters and Table S4 and figures (whole-brain FWE-corrected results), satisfying I5 and I6. No exclusion criteria apply (e.g., it is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes whole-brain task activation maps from healthy group).

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathic concern for characters in film clips) in healthy adults. The sample comprises 26 healthy adult participants (mean age 30.3), satisfying the age and healthy-sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise analyses (ANOVA and contrasts, Tables 1–2, and whole-brain figures) and parametric modulation results for the healthy group, which meet the whole-brain evidence criterion; results are presented in text, tables, and figures. The study additionally includes connectivity (DCM), but also reports univariate whole-brain activations, so it does not violate exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only or connectivity-only). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social communication/interaction in healthy adults (ages 18–27; final N=29). The task manipulates perceived live versus recorded speech and examines neural responses; authors report group-level whole-brain task contrasts (Live > Social; Social > Standard) with cluster-correction and figures/tables of results. Although ROI/localizer analyses are also reported, whole-brain voxelwise activation maps for the healthy sample are clearly presented and described. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adult sample, empirical fMRI data). Thus the study meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition/mentalizing: participants (N=20, healthy adults age 18–27) performed a task considering others’ mental states. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (searchlight and network-level representational similarity analysis) with cluster-corrected t-maps and tables/figures (Tables S2/S3, Figs. 2–4), satisfying whole-brain reporting. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria: I3 (fMRI during a social-related task), I4 (healthy adult sample within 18–65), I5 (group-level whole-brain voxelwise maps reported), and I6 (results presented in figures/tables). No exclusion criteria apply.

This fMRI study investigates social learning about others' generosity using a task that contrasts Gifters (social) with matched Lotteries (non-social). Participants are healthy adults (N=26 analyzed, ages 19–37). The paper reports voxelwise, group-level whole-brain GLM analyses with voxel-wise thresholding and whole-brain cluster correction, and presents tables and figures of whole-brain results. Therefore it satisfies the review criteria for inclusion: I3 (fMRI during a social-related task), I4 (healthy adult sample reported separately), I5 (group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps), and I6 (whole-brain results reported in tables/figures). No exclusion criteria appear to apply.

The full text appears to be a brief conference abstract that does not report necessary methodological details. While the study describes fMRI during a social task (live eye contact) suggesting I3 is met, it does not provide participant details (number, ages, or clearly identified healthy adult group) to confirm I4, nor does it present or reference any group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps (I5). Because the paper lacks reported healthy-group whole-brain task activation results, it fails the review’s required reporting standards and cannot be included.

The study is a proof-of-concept rt-fMRI/EEG neurofeedback correlation analysis targeting the right pSTS for social communication, but the manuscript reports correlations with a predefined ROI rather than reporting any group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for a healthy adult group.
