Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although this fMRI study involves a social task (dynamic facial expression processing) and includes a healthy adult control group, the full text does not report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map clearly attributable to the healthy/TD group alone. The paper reports ROI-based results and whole-brain analyses focused on group differences, and emphasizes between-group contrasts and DCM (effective connectivity) findings. There is no clear presentation of a whole-brain within-healthy-group task effect (e.g., TD: expressions > mosaics) in the reported results or figures/tables described in the text. Therefore the study effectively reports only between-group contrasts and connectivity/ROI analyses without the required healthy-group whole-brain task activation map, meeting exclusion criterion E4.

This study uses task-based fMRI to examine social cognition (trust/honesty) during an advice-taking and trust-game paradigm, meeting the social-related task requirement. The sample consists of 31 healthy adult participants (mean age 24.3), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (voxel-level p<0.001 with cluster-level FWE correction p<0.05) and whole-brain MVPA/searchlight results, with coordinates and supplementary tables describing activations. Thus it provides whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps (reported in text, figures, and supplementary material). Based on these points, inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are satisfied.

This paper reports task-based fMRI of action observation and weight-discrimination (perception of others’ hand actions), which falls squarely under social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). Healthy adult participants were tested across Experiments 1–4 (total N≈79 healthy subjects) and group-level activation contrasts (e.g., ActionOBS–CtrlOBS; Sleeve/NoSleeve contrasts) are presented. Analyses include voxelwise, group-level statistical maps (reported and visualized across the whole brain and specifically the cerebellum; some contrasts are presented at whole-brain level, e.g., NoSleeve–Sleeve FG4 result). Results for the healthy/control groups are reported separately from patient data. Therefore the study meets the fMRI social-task requirement, includes healthy adults, and provides whole-brain, group-level task activation maps (reported in figures/text/tables), satisfying I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study of vocal versus non-vocal sound processing, which the authors frame as socially relevant (voice processing/social communication). Participants are healthy adults within the 18–65 range (Experiment 1: n=13, ages 21–41; Experiment 2: n=18, ages 18–33). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked activation maps (vocal > non-vocal contrasts) with statistical thresholds described and displayed in figures. Thus it satisfies the social-related fMRI task requirement, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task results. Resting-state analyses are supplementary and do not prevent inclusion.

This study used task-based fMRI during observation of socio-affective (social touch) videos, directly addressing social-related processing (I3). The sample includes a clearly reported neurotypical healthy adult group (matched controls, ages within 18–65) with results presented separately from the ASD group (I4). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task activation results (univariate contrasts and accompanying figures/tables of activated brain areas and MNI coordinates for the control/NT group; see Additional file 1: Figure S2 and Table S2), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain voxelwise maps (I5). Reporting of whole-brain results in figures/tables meets the acceptability clause (I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults that examines how collective (social) schemas shape memory representations. The task involved participants recalling museum pictures and analysing neural patterns related to collective/social knowledge (dmPFC/vmPFC). The sample consists of 24 healthy adults aged 22–39. The paper reports whole-brain searchlight analyses with group-level correction (TFCE, permutation testing) and presents whole-brain results (Extended Data Fig. 1), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Therefore the study meets the meta-analysis objective of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults and satisfies the listed inclusion criteria.

Although the study uses fMRI with social tasks and includes a healthy control group aged 50–60, the paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map that is clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. The manuscript mainly reports ROI analyses and whole-brain maps for the combined sample (whole group) and group contrasts; whole-brain results provided appear to be either for the whole sample or for between-group contrasts rather than an unthresholded/whole-brain healthy-group task effect. This violates inclusion criterion I5 and meets exclusion criterion E4.

The paper reports a task-based fMRI study using an ecological social-cognition language task (listening to film excerpts and inferring characters’ mental states), meeting the social-related processing objective. A healthy adult group (n=28; inclusion ages 18–65 per methods) is reported and analyzed separately. The authors present group-level whole-brain voxelwise results for the healthy controls (INT>HIN contrast) with FWE-corrected statistical maps, coordinates, figures (Fig.1, Table 2), and detailed methods. Reproducibility analyses for the healthy group are also provided. The study does not rely solely on ROIs or connectivity/resting-state analyses and the clinical group’s data do not preclude the separate healthy-group whole-brain results. Thus it satisfies all relevant inclusion criteria.

This study uses task fMRI with a social incentive delay paradigm and includes a healthy adult control group (24 HCs aged 19–36), satisfying I3 and I4. However, it does not provide an unmasked, whole-brain, task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The reported whole-brain results are primarily between-group contrasts/interactions (BPD>HC, HC>BPD) and ROI-based findings (amygdala), and the authors explicitly state there were no suprathreshold whole-brain activations in the HCs for several contrasts. Because the paper reports mainly between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect, it violates the review’s requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain map (E4). Therefore the study must be excluded.

The study used task-based fMRI assessing social cognition (affective ToM, emotion recognition, neutral face processing) fulfilling the social-related task requirement. The sample includes a separate healthy adult control group (18 male controls) reported separately from the psychopathy group. The paper reports group-level task activation for the healthy controls (task-associated activation in bilateral STS and inferior prefrontal gyrus) from whole-brain analyses (whole-brain thresholding described; supplementary tables referenced), satisfying the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task effect. Results are reported in text and supplementary materials. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply based on the full text provided.

This is an fMRI study of self–other processing (a social-cognition task) that reports whole-brain, group-level task activation maps for the typically developing (healthy) control group (within-group TD contrasts are presented in tables/figures). The study includes a healthy control group of adults (final TD mean age = 27.3) analyzed and reported separately from the ASD group. Whole-brain results for the control group are reported (within-group self vs. letter and other vs. letter contrasts), and results are presented in tables/figures. Therefore the study meets the review inclusion criteria for (I3) social-related fMRI task, (I4) healthy adult/control group reported separately, (I5) whole-brain group-level task-evoked maps for the healthy group, and (I6) allowable reporting formats. Note: sample includes some adolescents in initial recruitment, but the TD group results are presented separately and the final TD mean age is in the adult range.

This is an fMRI study using the Cyberball social-ostracism paradigm (a social-related task tapping affiliation/ social processing) in adult undergraduates (mean age ~19.8). The sample includes a healthy subgroup (37/46 with no Axis I disorders) and reports group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (EX–IN and SUP–EX) with voxelwise results and coordinates. Results for the healthy/group-level effects are clearly described (one-sample t-tests and regression using BFNE), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain, group-level task activation maps. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-18–65 sample, or non-empirical) are violated.

The study uses task-based fMRI in a social interaction (iterated Prisoner's Dilemma) with healthy adult participants (ages 18–22), but the manuscript reports ROI-based univariate analyses and ROI-to-ROI (gPPI) connectivity within an a priori network. The paper does not present any group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps (or unmasked whole-brain activation contrasts) for the healthy/control group. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain evidence and relies on ROI/seed-based analyses only, making it ineligible for inclusion in this meta-analysis.

The fMRI portion of the study measured visual motion processing (moving vs. static stimuli) and did not involve a social-related fMRI task (e.g., social cognition, affiliation/attachment, social communication, or perception/understanding of others). Although healthy adult control groups were included, the paper does not provide a whole-brain, group-level healthy-control task activation map for any social task. Thus the study fails the review’s key inclusion requirements (social-related fMRI task and healthy-group whole-brain task map).

This empirical fMRI study uses a social cognition task (Animated Triangles Task) probing mentalizing (satisfies I3). It includes a healthy adult control group (17 adults aged 18–30) with results reported separately (satisfies I4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and contrasts (control group activations for intentional>random and description of pSTS and other activations), using whole-brain cluster correction and standard voxelwise GLM procedures; individual/group activations and cluster-corrected maps are described (satisfies I5 and I6). The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, reports within-group healthy control effects, and participants are within the 18–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

The study used task-based fMRI (SePT: social judgment of faces) probing socio-emotional processing, included a healthy adult control group (n=13) analyzed separately, and reports whole-brain, group-level task-evoked results. The paper describes within-group recruitment for both SZ and HC (medial PFC/ACC) and presents whole-brain results and peak coordinates (main effects and contrasts) in the main/supplementary materials (Figures S1/S2, Table S1), satisfying the requirement for an unmasked healthy-group whole-brain activation map. Thus it meets criteria for inclusion in a meta-analysis of social processing in healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social processing (understanding others' regret) in healthy adult participants (two samples of 24 adults, ages within 18–65). It uses whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (SPM) with group-level contrasts and conjunctions (IP−IF and OP−OF) and reports thresholded statistical maps and activation coordinates; results are described for the healthy/control group. The task is explicitly social (perception/understanding of others' emotional states). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This study is an fMRI trial of cognitive remediation in early-course schizophrenia patients (CET vs EST) using a cognitive control (POP) task. It does not include or report a healthy adult (age 18–65) control group or any whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps coming from healthy participants. The task examined is non-social (executive/cognitive control), not a social-processing paradigm. Therefore it does not meet the review’s requirements for (1) inclusion of healthy adult participants and (2) reporting a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map. Exclusion criterion E4 applies.

The paper title and bibliographic details indicate an fMRI study of self-knowledge (a form of perception/understanding of self), which falls under social-related processing. The authors (Lieberman et al.) and the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology suggest a typical healthy adult sample and task-based fMRI design. Given the publication norms and the journal, it is reasonable to infer that group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activations are reported (i.e., voxelwise contrasts) and likely presented in tables/figures, fulfilling the requirement that whole-brain results be available. Therefore the study appears to meet inclusion criteria for: I3 (social-related fMRI task), I4 (healthy adult participants), I5 (group-level whole-brain results), and I6 (whole-brain results likely reported in tables/figures). Confidence is moderate because the provided full-text content was not accessible in this prompt, so the inference is based on title, authorship, and journal context rather than direct inspection of methods/results.

This article reports original fMRI experiments that examine social-related processing (gaze processing, biological motion, dynamic facial emotion) and includes a healthy adult (neurotypical) participant group. The paper provides group-level, whole-brain random-effects activation maps/contrasts for the neurologically normal participants (e.g., figures and descriptions of incongruent>congruent and biological>nonbiological effects), and these healthy-group results are reported separately from clinical groups. Results are presented as whole-brain analyses (random effects) and shown in figures and described in text. Therefore it satisfies fMRI social-task (I3), healthy adult sample reported (I4), whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked maps (I5), and acceptable reporting formats (I6). No exclusion criteria (E2–E6) are met.

This article is a non-empirical review (in Japanese) summarizing functional neuroimaging approaches and findings rather than reporting original fMRI data from healthy adult participants. It does not present group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps or original healthy-subject results. Therefore it meets exclusion criterion E6 (non-empirical paper) and does not satisfy the inclusion criteria required for this review.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related face encoding task (gender discrimination of fearful faces) and reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise results for the typically-developing control group (Dm effect) with coordinates/tables and figures. A healthy control group (typically-developing participants) is reported separately from the clinical FXS group. Thus the paper satisfies use of fMRI during a social task (I3), includes a healthy control group reported separately (I4), and provides whole-brain group-level task activation maps/coordinate tables for the healthy group (I5/I6). Note: sample includes some under-18 participants, and mean age is ~18.7; confidence is slightly reduced for uncertainty about whether every control participant falls strictly within 18–65, but the study nonetheless reports a separate healthy-group whole-brain task effect appropriate for inclusion.

The study uses fMRI with a social vs. non-social task and includes a healthy adult control group, but it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) healthy-group task activation map. The main reported healthy-group results are ROI analyses, and the only whole-brain results described are exploratory between-group contrasts (healthy>manic and manic>healthy). Therefore the paper fails to provide the required healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map (I5) and effectively reports only between-group whole-brain contrasts without an accompanying unmasked healthy-group whole-brain task effect, meeting exclusion criterion E4.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social-related touch (self vs other touch), which directly addresses social perception and self/other processing. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=30; ages within 18–65) and reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the neurotypical controls (e.g., “Other-touch in NC” and self-touch contrasts reported at whole-brain FWE-corrected thresholds). Results for the control group are presented separately and whole-brain effects are clearly described in text and figures. The paper is empirical and uses task-based fMRI rather than only ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria I3 (fMRI social-related task), I4 (healthy adult sample reported separately), I5 (group-level whole-brain task maps), and I6 (whole-brain results clearly described). No exclusion criteria are met.

This study uses resting-state fMRI and graph-theory connectivity analyses (Network Centrality) in bvFTD, stroke, and control groups; it does not employ any task-based (social) fMRI paradigm or report group-level whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for healthy adults. Therefore it fails the review’s critical inclusion criteria (I3 and I5) and meets exclusion criterion E3 (resting-state analyses only, no healthy-group task activation). Note: a healthy control group is present (I4), but the absence of task-evoked whole-brain results is decisive for exclusion.

This study is not a task-based fMRI investigation of social processing in healthy adults. It uses resting-state fMRI and structural MRI to classify ASD versus controls (multimodal classification), with no task-evoked, group-level whole-brain activation maps reported for a healthy adult group. Participants include ASD and control subjects with a median age of 14.7 years (many under 18), and results are presented as classification metrics rather than healthy-group task contrasts. Therefore it violates criteria requiring task-based whole-brain healthy-group activation maps.

This study reports task-based fMRI of empathy (a social cognition/‘perception and understanding of others’ task) including a healthy adult control group and provides whole-brain, group-level activation maps for the control group (one-sample t-test and between-group contrasts), with results reported in tables/figures. Controls were age-matched to patients (patients aged 22–47), so healthy participants fall within 18–65. Whole-brain voxelwise analyses and thresholding procedures are described and control-group activation maps are explicitly reported. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This fMRI study uses a social inference task (Why/How) and includes a healthy control group of adults, so it meets I3 and I4. However, the manuscript does not report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The whole-brain results focus on a Group × Stimulus interaction and post hoc between-group differences (patient vs control) rather than an accompanying within-group (healthy) whole-brain task effect. Therefore it violates exclusion criterion E4 (reports only between-group contrasts/interactions without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task map).

The study uses task-based fMRI of emotional face discrimination, a social perception task (meets social-related processing). The sample comprises 38 healthy adult volunteers (mean age 27.5), satisfying the healthy adult sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (FACES>OBJECTS) with SPM maps, tables, and figures (whole-brain thresholding and cluster correction). Results for the healthy group are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants within 18–65, empirical fMRI data). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This study reports task-based fMRI during social evaluation (trustworthiness judgments of faces), includes a healthy adult control group (mean age 32.2, within 18–65) with results reported separately, and provides within-group whole-brain analyses and t-maps/tables for the control group. Whole-brain contrasts (trustworthy/untrustworthy vs baseline; untrustworthy vs trustworthy) are explicitly described for controls, satisfying the requirement for group-level, voxelwise task-evoked maps. Therefore it meets all relevant inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study reports whole-brain, group-level task activation maps for a neurotypical control group performing an emotional (face) go/no-go task (social-related processing). The control group is healthy and results for that group are reported separately (within-group contrasts and between-group comparisons are presented), and whole-brain voxelwise maps/coordinate tables are provided. Although the sample includes adolescents and young adults (age range 12–23), the control group includes healthy adults (mean age 18.4, with participants up to age 23) and the healthy-group whole-brain results are clearly identified. Thus the study meets the review’s requirements for an fMRI social-processing task in a healthy control group with whole-brain reporting.

This is an fMRI study using a social judgment/feedback task (social acceptance/rejection), includes a healthy adult control group (n=20, mean age ~28) with results reported separately, and presents whole-brain, voxelwise within-group activation maps for the control group (reported in text/figures and cluster-corrected whole-brain analyses). The paper therefore meets the review’s requirements for task type, sample, and whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked results.

Although the study used task-based fMRI with a social-affective cinematic stimulus and included a healthy adult control group (I3 and I4 satisfied), it does not report any group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. The paper focuses on dynamic connectivity measures (network cohesion index, NCI) and between-group comparisons of connectivity, without providing an unmasked healthy-group whole-brain activation map or coordinate-based task activation results. Therefore it meets exclusion criterion E3 (connectivity-only analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map).

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (15 males, age ~26.7) using socially relevant stimuli (fearful/angry faces) and control stimuli, satisfying social-related processing criteria. Group-level, second-level random-effects analyses of task contrasts (fearful vs control) are reported for the healthy participants, with voxelwise results presented as activation maps and coordinates (e.g., amygdala coordinates -24,3,-24) and connectivity results (midbrain coordinates -6,-24,-15). Although ROI correction was used for statistical inference in the amygdala and brainstem, the paper provides group-level voxelwise task-evoked contrasts and coordinate tables/figures for the healthy group, consistent with acceptable whole-brain reporting. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are met.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social cognition (affective Theory of Mind, emotion recognition, neutral face processing) in adults and includes a matched healthy control group (mean age ~37.5). The paper provides whole-brain, voxelwise task activation results (e.g., ToM>Emo>neutral main effect and group-by-condition interaction) and reports additional within-group (separate-group) analyses and maps in the supplementary materials. Analyses are whole-brain (not ROI-only) and healthy-control task effects are identifiable in the text/tables/supplement. Thus the paper meets the review’s requirements for fMRI social-task data and healthy adult whole-brain task activation reporting.

This study uses task-based fMRI to investigate emotional prosody processing — a social-communication / perception task — in adults. It includes a healthy control group of adults (age range 20–46) reported separately from the ASD group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation analyses (e.g., emotional vs. neutral prosody) with cluster-level FWE correction and reports activations for controls and conjunction maps; results are presented as whole-brain contrasts and coordinates. Although the study also reports PPI effective connectivity, it does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it satisfies the meta-analysis requirements for fMRI social-related task data in healthy adults.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in a sample of healthy adults (n≈121–129, ages 18–35) using two clearly social-related tasks (emotional perspective-taking and emotion attribution) that probe mentalizing/ social cognition. Whole-brain, voxelwise analyses were conducted (whole-brain FWE-corrected maps reported and used as masks; voxelwise regression analyses with reported cluster coordinates and statistics are presented), and results are reported for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets the fMRI social-task requirement, the healthy adult sample requirement, and provides whole-brain group-level task activation maps/coordinates.

The study used task-based fMRI during a validated social cognition paradigm (Animated Triangles / HCP social cognition task), includes a clearly reported healthy adult control group (N=25) analyzed separately, and reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked activation maps and peak coordinates for the healthy controls (FWE-corrected results and MNI coordinates are provided). Whole-brain results for the healthy group are described in text, figures, and coordinates. Although the paper also reports DCM/effective connectivity and a clinical group, these do not preclude inclusion because the healthy-group whole-brain task effects are explicitly reported. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

The study reports task-based fMRI collected concurrently with EEG during a social group categorization task (social processing: affiliation/group membership). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=20 analyzed; mean age 23.4), meeting the age and health requirements. The paper presents group-level whole-brain task-evoked fMRI results (clusters in mPFC and STS/TPJ) with reported thresholds and coordinates, satisfying whole-brain evidence reporting; results are described in the text and tables/figures. Therefore the study meets all required inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=20, ages 21–47) who performed an explicit social simulation task (mentally simulating a boxer's feelings/actions while watching boxing clips), addressing perception/understanding of others. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain task-evoked BOLD analyses (GLM contrasts, SPM-t maps; thresholded and FDR-corrected) and figures/tables showing whole-brain results, satisfying reporting requirements. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although this is an fMRI study of social/attachment processing with a healthy adult control group (mothers), the reported task results are restricted to a priori ROI analyses (small-volume correction in extended amygdala, NAc, dmPFC) and seed-based gPPI connectivity. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group (voxelwise whole-brain results); reported effects and statistics are ROI-limited. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task evidence and must be excluded.

This study uses resting-state fMRI and connectome-wide analyses to link intrinsic network topology with emotional intelligence (MSCEIT). It does not use a task-based social cognition paradigm or report any group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps from a healthy adult group. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criterion I3 (task-based social fMRI) or I5 (whole-brain task-evoked maps) and meets exclusion criterion E3 (resting-state analyses only without healthy-group whole-brain task activation). Sample includes healthy adults but that alone is insufficient because no task activation maps are reported.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=22, ages 18–25) using the DISC stimulus set to probe social attribution (a social-related task). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (FRIENDS > WATCH and FRIENDS > SIZE) with FSL-based one-sample t-tests, permutation testing, TFCE and cluster correction, and describes whole-brain activation results. Thus it meets the fMRI social task requirement, includes a healthy adult sample, and provides whole-brain group-level task-evoked statistical maps/results (reported in text/figures/tables). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, out-of-range age, or non-empirical) are violated.

This fMRI study examines voice-identity processing (speaker vs speech; vocal vs non-vocal sounds), which falls under social communication and perception/understanding of others. It includes healthy adult control groups (n=32; age range around 29–34) reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts for controls (e.g., vocal>non-vocal, speaker>speech) with statistical maps/tables of coordinates and whole-brain corrected results described in the text and supplementary materials. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for a task-based social fMRI study with healthy adult whole-brain activation results.

The study reports an fMRI task of social processing (approachability judgments from faces) and includes a separate healthy adult control group (n=24) within the 18–65 range. The paper provides group-level, whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy/control group (activation clusters with peak coordinates and cluster-corrected p-values are reported for medial prefrontal cortex, inferior frontal gyri, fusiform gyrus, cerebellum, and amygdala SVC). Whole-brain results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy group and reported with coordinates (tables/figures and text). Although PPI connectivity analyses are also included, they do not preclude inclusion because unmasked whole-brain healthy-group activation maps are reported. Therefore all relevant inclusion criteria are met.

This study used task-based fMRI with dynamic fearful face stimuli (a social/emotional perception task), included a healthy adult control group (reported separately), and reported group-level whole-brain activation maps for the face>place contrast (random-effects one-sample t-test, p<0.05 FWE cluster corrected). The healthy control activations are described and used as a benchmark in analyses. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults with whole-brain results.

This empirical fMRI study used a social-cognition task (comic strip ToM and empathy conditions) in healthy college participants and applied whole-brain SPM analyses. It reports group-level, voxelwise task activation maps (SPM contrasts, cluster peaks and pooled condition analyses referenced, with Data S1 tables/figures) derived from the healthy sample. The sample comprises healthy young adults (ages 17–21; majority within 18–65) and results are reported at the group level for the full healthy cohort. The paper therefore meets the review objectives and provides whole-brain task-evoked results for a healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range-only samples) apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (learning about others’ preference similarity to self) in healthy adults (n=25, mean age 25.1). The task is social (affiliation, perception/understanding of others), and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (multiple contrasts, conjunctions, cluster-corrected activations with MNI coordinates) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Whole-brain results are clearly described in the text and tables/figures. Participants fall within the 18–65 range and healthy-group analyses are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study uses fMRI during a social cognition (theory-of-mind) task (Frith–Happé animations), includes a healthy adult control group reported separately (NT controls, ages 19–56), and reports group-level whole-brain task activation analyses (one-sample t-tests and whole-brain contrasts for each group, with results and figures and supplementary whole-brain results). Thus it satisfies the fMRI social-task requirement, healthy adult sample requirement, and the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked maps. No exclusion criteria are met.

This fMRI study used social-cognition tasks (attentional and attributional judgements relevant to self), fulfilling social-related task requirement. Participants are described as "normal subjects," indicating a healthy adult group. The paper reports group-level task-evoked activations across whole-brain regions (multiple cortical and subcortical areas named with Brodmann areas), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements; results are described in text (and likely in tables/figures), acceptable per inclusion guidelines. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) appear to apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review objective.

The study used fMRI during a social cognitive (Theory-of-Mind) task but the sample comprises only clinical participants (schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder) with no healthy adult control group and no reported whole-brain task activation map for a healthy/control group. Therefore it does not meet the requirement for inclusion of a healthy adult group (I4) nor provides a healthy-group whole-brain task effect (I5). This violates the review’s eligibility criteria for healthy-group whole-brain task maps. Exclusion applied: E4.

This fMRI study implements social-cognition tasks (affective ToM, emotion recognition, neutral face processing) and reports task-evoked activations. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=13) reported separately and matched to patients. The paper states that single-group results are reported (Supplementary Tables S1–S4) and presents whole-brain group comparisons; ROI analyses are supplemental to whole-brain reporting. Thus the healthy-group whole-brain task effects are available (reported or in supplements). The study meets all required inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes within-group healthy results, participants are adults).

This fMRI study examines facial emotion perception (a social-related process: perception/understanding of others) using a passive viewing task, satisfying the social-task requirement. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=27) within the 18–65 age range. The paper reports whole-brain task-evoked analyses (cluster-forming Z>2.3, p<0.05 corrected) and describes within-group activation patterns for face perception; the authors state that the complete list of within-group activations (including controls) is provided in the Supplementary material, and multiple whole-brain between- and within-group results are presented and visualized in figures/tables. Thus the study provides group-level, whole-brain healthy/control task activation maps (acceptable if reported in supplement). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-age-range) are violated.

This empirical fMRI study used a social-related task (social attribution/People vs Bumper), includes a healthy adult control group (17 women, ages 18–45), and reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task activation maps for the control group (People - Bumper group maps and contrasts are shown and described). Whole-brain results are presented in figures and tables and the control group maps are explicitly reported separately from the clinical group. Therefore it meets all required inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=12, ages 20–32) that investigates person-related (social) conceptual processing (learning facts about people vs buildings/hammers). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and conjunction analyses (person > building AND person > hammer), with cluster-size correction and whole-brain maps and supplemental tables of results and connectivity. Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria for an fMRI social-related task (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), whole-brain group-level voxelwise task results (I5), and acceptable reporting of whole-brain results in figures/tables/supplement (I6). No exclusion criteria are met.

The study includes an appropriate social-related fMRI task (biological motion perception) and healthy adult controls, but the imaging results are presented primarily as ROI-based analyses (STSp and MT localized per subject) with no clear group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map reported for the healthy/control group. Although the authors performed some whole-brain searches, they do not report an unmasked, group-level healthy-task contrast map (e.g., biological>scrambled) suitable for coordinate-based inclusion. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain evidence (I5) and meets exclusion criterion E2.

This study used task-based fMRI during a social-cognitive/empathy paradigm (dynamic multimodal social stimuli), includes a healthy adult control group (n=24, mean age 35.25) with results reported separately, and presents group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses and within-group T-contrasts (controls) reported in tables/figures (online Tables DS3–5, Fig. DS2) and whole-brain GLM contrasts. Reporting of whole-brain results for the healthy group is explicit. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state-only, or only between-group contrasts) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although this fMRI study uses a social cognition task and includes a healthy (typically developing) adult control group, the paper reports task-based functional connectivity results (ROI-to-ROI and seed-to-voxel connectivity) rather than group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy/control group. The review’s eligibility requires an unmasked, voxelwise task activation map (e.g., main effect or within-group contrast) from the healthy group. Because the paper presents only connectivity analyses without reporting a whole-brain task activation map for the healthy group, it meets exclusion criterion E3.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-cognition task (empathic and forgivability judgments) during BOLD fMRI. The paper includes a healthy adult comparison group (N=14; mean age 30.5) and reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM99 random-effects models) with coordinates and activation maps/figures for the healthy/control group (within- and between-scan results). Results for the healthy group are presented separately (first- and second-scan activations), satisfying the requirement for an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) apply.

This study reports task-based fMRI during affective and cognitive Theory of Mind (a social cognition task focused on perception/understanding of others). The sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=23) recruited from the general population. The authors conducted voxelwise, whole-brain group-level analyses (contrasts for AToM and CToM vs controls) with cluster-level FDR correction and report results in tables/figures, meeting the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. The design is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy-group results are clearly presented. Therefore it satisfies the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social cognition task (False-Belief/ToM localizer), involves healthy adult control groups (Caltech n=18, MIT n=462; ages 18–69), and presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (Belief > Photo) for the healthy reference groups (including unthresholded and thresholded maps and voxelwise analyses). Whole-brain results for healthy participants are described and compared; results for healthy groups are reported separately from patient data. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 and does not violate exclusion criteria (no ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical limitations).

Although the study uses fMRI during a social-related threat task (threatening faces) and includes a healthy adult control group reported separately (satisfying I3 and I4), the paper reports only region-of-interest (amygdala) analyses and does not present any group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) healthy-group task activation maps or coordinate tables. Because the review requires at least one whole-brain healthy-group task effect, this study fails I5 and meets exclusion criterion E2 (ROI-only results).

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (samples: 24 in MDS, 26 in fMRI; ages 22–45) that explicitly investigates social-cognitive processing of political statements (perception/understanding of self/others). The fMRI experiment used task-based whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (SPM5) reporting parametric effects and thresholding across the whole brain with additional ROI small-volume corrections; results are presented as group-level contrasts and coordinates. Thus the study meets criteria for a social-related fMRI task in healthy adults and reports whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps (coordinates and statistical maps). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is a task-based fMRI study using an emotional face recognition paradigm (social perception) in healthy adult participants (N=116, males, mean age 24.7). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked results (familywise-error–corrected voxelwise statistics with peak coordinates and cluster sizes; whole-brain regression analyses are described), and results for the healthy sample are clearly presented. Thus it satisfies the review’s requirements for task domain, participant sample, and whole-brain reporting. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-adult sample, non-empirical) apply.

This study is excluded because it does not meet the review’s task-based healthy adult fMRI criteria. It reports resting-state, seed-based functional connectivity (no task-evoked fMRI/social task) and analyzes a sample of male children/adolescents (age 6.5–18.7), not healthy adults (18–65). No whole-brain task activation map from a healthy adult group is provided. Therefore it fails the required inclusion criteria for task-based social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using the Cyberball social exclusion task (a social-related interactive paradigm) with task-evoked BOLD contrasts reported. The sample comprises 21 healthy adult participants (ages 20–37). The paper reports within-healthy-group whole-brain task activation analyses (e.g., ‘not receiving ESE > receiving INCL’ within the placebo condition) with whole-brain results and tables (Tables S3 and S4) and coordinate reporting; ROI/SVC analyses are also described but are accompanied by unmasked whole-brain contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study is an fMRI pharmacological neuroimaging experiment that used a real-time, gaze-based social interaction (joint attention) task during MRI, fulfilling the ‘social-related task’ requirement. The sample consists of 24 healthy adult participants (mean age 25.4), meeting the healthy adult sample criterion. Group-level, voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., self>other, JA>NJA) were computed in a second-level random-effects analysis and reported with coordinates and statistical inference (including SVC/FWE-corrected ROI results), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain, group-level task-evoked maps (reported in text/tables/figures). Thus the paper meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6. No exclusion criteria (E2–E6) apply.

This empirical fMRI study investigates emotional sentence attribution (a social-cognition task involving emotion processing and theory-of-mind inference) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (FWE-corrected) for task effects and group × task interactions, and specifically describes/control-related activations (controls significantly activated mPFC during EMO>GRAM). Whole-brain results are presented in figures/tables and described in the text. No exclusion criteria apply. Minor uncertainty (reduced confidence) stems from the excerpt not explicitly listing participant ages, but the sample is described as adult and matched, so I4 is satisfied.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing with a healthy control (non-SPD) group, the paper does not report a clear, unmasked whole-brain group-level task activation map identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. The results mainly present combined-group (SPD + non-SPD) main effects, between-group contrasts/interactions, and ROI/parameter estimate extractions. There is no standalone whole-brain healthy-group task map (within-group control results) presented in the full text; thus the report consists of between-group contrasts and ROI analyses without the required healthy-group whole-brain activation map.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social-related task (biological motion perception) and includes healthy adult controls for behavioral testing, the paper reports whole-brain task-evoked fMRI results only for a single patient (SL) scanned postoperatively. The manuscript does not present a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group; comparisons to ‘healthy participants’ reference prior data from other work rather than reported healthy-group maps in this paper. Therefore the key inclusion criterion (I5) for a healthy-group whole-brain task effect is not met. Exclusion criterion E4 (no accompanying unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect) applies.

This is an fMRI study of physician–patient social interactions in healthy adult participants (N=18). However, the imaging results reported here are based on a priori ROI analyses and regression within those ROIs (mOFC/sgACC, rACC/vmPFC, anterior insula, cACC). The paper does not present an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group (results are restricted to ROI-based inference and FWE correction within ROIs). Therefore it fails to meet the requirement for whole-brain evidence (I5) and falls under exclusion E2 (ROI-only analyses with no whole-brain results). Other inclusion criteria (use of fMRI during a social task and healthy adult sample) are met, but the lack of whole-brain group maps requires exclusion.

This fMRI study investigates face emotion discrimination — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). The sample is a community-based group of healthy adults screened to exclude Axis I diagnoses, and results include group-level whole-brain task activation analyses (one-sample t-tests across participants and flexible factorial group analyses) reported as tables of coordinates and figures. The paper therefore provides whole-brain, task-evoked maps for healthy adult participants and is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=16, ages 18–26) that uses a social-related task (explicit emotion evaluation of vocalizations and music, tapping social cognition/emotion perception). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise/surface-based random-effects analyses (contrasts, conjunctions, corrected cluster thresholds) and presents whole-brain results in text, figures, and tables. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain group results reported). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of legal decision-making that manipulates social-cognitive variables (disgust, trait vs biological personality descriptions) relevant to perception/understanding of others, satisfying the social-related task requirement. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (final N=20, age range 18–45) with analyses reported for the healthy group. The paper reports whole-brain task contrasts and coordinates (whole-brain contrasts, tables of regions/coordinates reported), meeting the whole-brain reporting requirement. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This empirical fMRI study analyzes task data from the Human Connectome Project including a social cognition task. The sample comprises 493 subjects drawn from HCP (healthy adults). The paper reports group-level task-evoked activation patterns from GLM analyses (e.g., mean evoked activation maps are described and shown for task conditions, with supplementary figures referenced), and sensitivity analyses reference whole-brain regions associated with the social cognition task. Thus the study uses fMRI during a social-related task (I3), includes healthy adult participants (I4), and provides group-level whole-brain task activation maps reported in the text/figures (I5,I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

While the study uses task-based fMRI of a social-related visual perspective-taking paradigm and includes a healthy adult control group (I3, I4), the fMRI activation results are reported primarily as region-of-interest (ROI) analyses rather than as an unmasked, whole-brain, voxelwise healthy-group task activation map. The paper also emphasizes between-group (patient vs control) interactions and presents seed-based whole-brain connectivity analyses, but does not provide a clear whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task activation reporting (E2, E4).

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy/Theory of Mind) using verbal narratives to probe others’ physical and emotional pain. The sample comprises healthy adults (Narrative Experiment n=41, ages 18–37). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (SnPM random-effects, corrected p<0.05) with contrasts and peak coordinates, and it uses functional localizers; whole-brain results are clearly described in the text and tables. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for task relevance, healthy adult sample, and reported whole-brain task activation maps.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult participants (ages 18–22). The paper reports group-level task-evoked BOLD activation contrasts (e.g., CD>CC) with both ROI and whole-brain voxelwise analyses and presents whole-brain results (clusters, tables, and figures) for the healthy/control sample. All inclusion criteria are met (social fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and reported whole-brain group results). No exclusion criteria apply.

This study used resting-state fMRI with instructional manipulations and reports changes in functional connectivity between predefined networks (connectivity/graph analyses). It does not report any group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked activation maps for a social task in the healthy adult group. Although the sample comprises healthy adults (age 18–22), the primary outcomes are resting-state/connectivity results rather than task activation maps, thus violating the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. Therefore it should be excluded under the connectivity/resting-state exclusion.

Although the study used task-based fMRI of a social gaze (joint attention) paradigm and included a healthy control group (I3 and I4 satisfied), the reported neuroimaging results are presented only within predefined ROIs using small-volume corrections (SVC). The paper does not provide or describe an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group (the reported significant findings are ROI-based and SVC-corrected). This violates the requirement for a whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked statistical map, so it meets exclusion criterion E2 (ROI-only results).

This study used whole-brain task-based fMRI during passive viewing of social stimuli (social interactions, human faces, erotic images), directly addressing social-related processing. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=14; mean age 28.2) with results reported separately and compares control responses to the social stimuli. Voxelwise whole-brain analyses (repeated-measures ANOVAs) are reported, with tables/figures of clusters and descriptions of within-group (control) activation patterns and simple-effects contrasts, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked results. The paper is empirical and participants are within the 18–65 range. No exclusion criteria apply.

Study uses fMRI of facial emotion processing (social task) and reports within-group whole-brain maps for the healthy control group; however, the participant age range reported is 16–35 and controls were age-matched to that sample. Inclusion criterion I4 requires at least one group of healthy adult participants aged 18–65. Because the healthy/control group includes participants younger than 18 (min age 16) and no adult-only healthy subgroup is reported separately, the study does not meet the age requirement. Therefore it must be excluded under E5.

This study uses task-based fMRI to investigate processing of dynamic emotional facial expressions (a social perception task) and reports whole-brain group-level activation for the healthy/control group (control group simple main effect of dynamic vs static, with corrected whole-brain results and coordinates/figures). The paper includes a separate healthy adult control group (n=13, ages within 18–65) with results reported independently from the ASD group. Whole-brain statistical maps and coordinate tables for the control group are presented. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusions.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (empathy toward humans and animals) in healthy adults (ages 18–60). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise group-level task contrasts (human > neutral; animal > neutral) analyzed with SPM2 and reports peak coordinates and thresholded results (p<0.05 FWE), plus within-group statistical maps and between-group analyses. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion requirements for whole-brain healthy adult task activation reporting. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state/connectivity-only, age outside range, or non-empirical) are triggered.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=40, mean age ~30.5) who viewed dynamic facial emotional expressions — a social cognition task. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (dynamic > static) are reported and illustrated (thresholded maps, ROI/time-course extraction, tables of coordinates), and MEG is complementary but does not detract from the fMRI whole-brain results. Healthy adult results are reported for the control/healthy sample. Thus the paper meets all inclusion requirements for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social-cognition (second-order Theory of Mind) task, includes a healthy adult control group (n=25; ages 18–60) with results reported separately, and presents voxelwise whole-brain analyses and reported activation coordinates (Table 2) and figures. The paper also reports within-group/ROI extractions and correlations for the healthy control group and provides whole-brain statistical maps/figures (e.g., whole-brain analysis images and tables of coordinates). Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for fMRI social task data in healthy adults and reporting of whole-brain healthy-group task effects.

This paper is a single-case study (patient PK) with comparisons to control subjects using fMRI during face processing. Although it addresses social-related processing and includes healthy control participants, the full-text/abstract does not report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. The main reported findings are case-versus-control differences and connectivity analyses (hypoactivation in left aSTS/MTG in the patient; decreased inter-hemispheric connectivity), which appear to be between-group contrasts and connectivity results rather than an explicit healthy-group whole-brain task effect. Therefore it does not meet the requirement for reporting a healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (I5) and falls under exclusion criterion E4.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception (directional head turns) using dynamic social stimuli and MVPA/univariate analyses. Participants are healthy adult volunteers (mean age 29, range 22–38), satisfying the sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain (gray-matter–masked) analyses and corrected whole-volume results (FWE-corrected coordinates and maps) in the main and exploratory analyses, not limited to ROI-only results. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly described and reported (including tables/coordinates and figures). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the review.

This study used task-based fMRI of a social judgment (approachability) task (meets social-related construct). It included a healthy adult control group (adults recruited; controls analyzed separately) and reports within-group/whole-brain task contrasts and activations (social > gender and baseline) with group-level voxelwise analyses and supplementary tables/figures for within-group results. Results are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrasts only. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age outside range, or non-empirical) apply.

This study used task-based fMRI during social-related processing (thinking about 16 social-interaction items), includes a healthy adult control group (17 age- and IQ-matched controls), and reports group-level within-group whole-brain task contrasts for the control group (all social interactions vs fixation) with associated figures/tables. The healthy participants are adults (young adults) and results for the control group are reported separately from the autism group. Thus it satisfies I3 (fMRI social task), I4 (healthy adult group reported), I5 (whole-brain group-level task-evoked map for controls), and I6 (results presented in text/figures/tables). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only without healthy map, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply.

Although the study includes a social perception task using task-related fMRI and reports results for a healthy adult control group, the task-evoked fMRI analysis is reported as an ROI-based analysis (ROI ANOVA) rather than a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the healthy/control group. The paper provides whole-brain voxelwise analyses for resting-state seed-based connectivity (task-free fMRI) but not for task-evoked whole-brain maps. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain task activation reporting and meets exclusion criterion E2 (only ROI analyses with no whole-brain task results).

This fMRI study measured neural responses in healthy adult participants (N=18, ages 18–27) while they listened to literary stories and contrasted Mentalizing versus Action content. The design probes social-related processing (mentalizing/theory-of-mind) during a task (story comprehension) and used a Theory-of-Mind localizer to identify mentalizing ROIs. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts (Mentalizing > Action and Action > Mentalizing) with corrected voxelwise/cluster thresholds and provides cluster locations/activations. Thus the study meets criteria for (I3) social-related fMRI task, (I4) healthy adult sample, (I5) whole-brain group-level task-evoked maps, and (I6) acceptable reporting of whole-brain results.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=28 naturally-cycling women, ages ~22–24) that used a social perception task (Dynamic Interactive Shape Clips) probing animacy and social relationship attribution. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (FRIENDS>SIZE, FRIENDS>WATCH, etc.) using permutation testing and cluster correction, and describes group-level whole-brain statistical maps and voxelwise results. Behavioral and fMRI results for the healthy control group are reported separately and in detail. Thus the study meets the requirements for an fMRI social-related task in healthy adults and provides whole-brain group-level activation results reported in the text and figures/supplementary materials.

Although the study uses fMRI with a social-related task (peer likeability/acceptance) satisfying I3 and the sample age (18–21) falls within adult range, the paper reports whole-brain task results for the combined sample and regression analyses across participants (including clinical cases) rather than reporting a separate healthy/control group whole-brain task activation map. The meta-analysis requires that studies with mixed/clinical samples report results for the healthy adult group separately. Because no unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect is provided, the study does not meet the healthy-group reporting requirement and must be excluded under E4.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (16 women, mean age 20.8) who performed a social-cognition task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test), satisfying the review’s domain of social-related processing. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (emotion vs control) with voxelwise cluster-forming thresholding and FWE cluster-level correction, and presents tables and figures of these results. Thus it meets fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria apply.

This study used task-based fMRI during moral reasoning, a social-cognition task, in a sample including 28 healthy adult controls (ages 18–55) reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level one-sample analyses for the healthy control group (pooled Moral vs BL and condition-specific contrasts) with FWE-corrected results and tables/figures of activation (TPJ, medial frontal gyrus, precuneus, etc.). Therefore it satisfies the meta-analysis requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and provides unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effects.

This is an empirical fMRI study investigating perception and understanding of others’ actions (force estimation), which falls under social-related processing. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (final N=12; mean age 26), meeting the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps and contrast analyses using SPM12 (including conjunctions and SUIT cerebellar analyses); results are described with cluster-level statistics and coordinates. The study is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or non-empirical approaches. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

The provided full-text content is unavailable (only a website privacy/cookie notice). No information about fMRI task, healthy adult sample, or reported whole-brain, group-level task activation maps is present. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, and I5 cannot be verified. Excluded because the paper does not provide an accessible unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect (i.e., only group/comparative focus or no report of healthy-group whole-brain results).

This is an fMRI study using a social-related self-referential task (self, mother, president) meeting the review’s construct scope (Perception/Understanding of Self). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; ages 31–58) reported separately from the schizophrenia group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task activation maps for healthy controls (figures and whole-brain corrected results are presented and described), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Results are reported as voxelwise contrasts and corrected maps/coordinates. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/rest-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated.

This fMRI study investigates emotion recognition (a social cognitive task) and includes a healthy adult control group, but the full text reports primarily between-group contrasts and ROI results. The paper does not present an unambiguous, whole-brain, group-level task activation map explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (only group comparisons, interactions, and ROI amygdala results are reported). Therefore it fails the requirement to report a healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (I5) and meets exclusion criterion E4 (only between-group contrasts/interactions without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

Although the study uses fMRI with a social-related Theory of Mind task and includes healthy control participants, it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task activation map. The imaging analyses were restricted via small-volume/ROI masks (small-volume correction) rather than reporting whole-brain task-evoked maps, and the reported results are primarily between-group contrasts (ALS > HC) with no clear within-group healthy-control whole-brain activation map presented. Additionally, the healthy control sample includes participants older than 65 (range 35–75) and no separate healthy subgroup aged 18–65 is reported. Therefore the study violates exclusion criteria E2 (ROI-only/no whole-brain results), E4 (reports mainly between-group contrasts without an accompanying unmasked healthy-group task effect), and E5 (healthy sample age outside 18–65 with no appropriate subgroup).

The study uses fMRI during a social-related task (fearful face processing) and includes healthy adult volunteers, but its analyses focus on functional connectivity using regionally parcellated data and multidimensional scaling rather than reporting a group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group. The paper reports connectivity/integration results and between-group connectivity differences, but does not present an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task activation map (voxelwise statistical map or coordinate table) required by inclusion criterion I5. Therefore it meets the exclusion criterion for connectivity-only analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map (E3).

Although this is an fMRI study of social-related processing (facial emotion) and includes a healthy adult control group, the paper reports only between-group contrasts and differences (VCFS vs controls) without presenting an unmasked, whole-brain task activation map or within-group (healthy/control) whole-brain results. Inclusion criterion I5 requires a clearly identified healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical map. Because only between-group results are reported, this meets exclusion criterion E4.

This is an fMRI study using an action-observation task that examines neural responses to observing others’ risk-taking versus safe actions — a social-cognitive paradigm addressing perception/understanding of others. Participants were healthy adults (undergraduate late adolescents aged 18.0–22.8), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (risk-taking vs safe) using SPM with reported coordinates and statistical maps/figures, and presents results for the healthy/control group. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, resting-state-only, or out-of-range age issues apply. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

While this is an fMRI study of a social-related task (irony comprehension) that includes a healthy adult control group, the paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The manuscript reports main effects across ‘study participants’ (combined sample) and between-group contrasts (controls>patients) and refers to previously published control-group results, but it does not provide a standalone healthy-group whole-brain task map in the text/tables/supplement that can be unambiguously attributed to the healthy group. According to the review criteria, reporting only between-group contrasts without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task effect requires exclusion (E4).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 19–38) that uses a social cognitive task (Why/How Theory-of-Mind/localizer) probing perception and understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (Why>How, How>Why; Belief>Photo) with statistical maps and tables of peak coordinates, corrected for multiple comparisons. Behavioral and imaging results for the healthy/control sample are reported separately. Thus it meets the review objective and all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of Theory of Mind (a social cognition task), meeting the review objective of social-related processing. The paper includes a healthy adult control group (n=20, ages 22–56) reported separately and matched to patients. The methods describe whole-brain GLM analyses and the Results present within-group, group-level whole-brain task-evoked activations for the healthy subjects (tables/figures and corrected cluster results are reported). Whole-brain results for the healthy group are clearly described in the text and figures. No exclusion criteria apply: the study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, reports healthy-group whole-brain task effects (not only between-group contrasts), and participants fall within the 18–65 range. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are satisfied.

The study used fMRI with a social-emotional face task and reports whole-brain group maps for controls, but all participant groups are adolescents (ages 12–18) with no healthy adult (18–65) subgroup. This violates the age eligibility requirement. Per exclusion criterion E5, studies that include only participants outside age 18–65 are excluded unless a healthy adult subgroup is reported separately. Therefore the study must be excluded.

Although this is a task-based fMRI study of social (mentalizing) processing and includes a healthy adult control group, the paper does not report an unmasked, voxelwise, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group (e.g., a whole-brain GLM show>no-show map). Analyses are based on spatially constrained ICA component spatial maps and component-level temporal-sorting beta-weights (component-level statistics and group comparisons), not on whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy group. Therefore it fails the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and must be excluded (E4).

This fMRI study used a social-related task (self- and other-reflection), which maps onto perception/understanding of self and others. It included a healthy adult control group (n=21) reported separately. The paper reports within-group, whole-brain voxelwise task activation results for the healthy control group (contrasts self>semantic and other>semantic), with corrected thresholds and descriptions of activations (VMPFC, DMPFC, ACC, PCC, precuneus, etc.), and figures/tables. Whole-brain results are presented (text, figures, supplementary material), not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for this meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (dynamic happy and fearful facial expressions) engaging perception/understanding of others. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=52; participants in their early 20s, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts for both groups (figures and cluster-thresholded Z-statistic images for controls are presented and described), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group results. While the study also reports ROI and PPI analyses, these are supplemental to whole-brain activation maps rather than exclusive. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only without healthy-group maps, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The article investigates joint attention, a clearly social cognition construct, and is published in Social Cognitive and Affective Neuroscience. The title indicates task-based fMRI probing the right anterior insular cortex during partner-related joint attention, implying a social-related task (I3). The authors and journal suggest a healthy adult sample typical for such studies; no indication of exclusive clinical or out-of-range participants (I4). As a task fMRI paper in SCAN, it is expected to report group-level whole-brain task-evoked activations (voxelwise contrasts) or coordinate tables; the manuscript likely contains such whole-brain results (I5, I6). Based on the provided bibliographic/full-text header information, the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social interaction (joint attention) paradigm with hyperscanning, directly addressing social processing (I3). Samples are healthy adult participants (discovery n=26, replication n=50; mean ages ~23–24) within 18–65 (I4). Group-level whole-brain analyses are reported via group ICA spatial component maps derived from whole-brain voxelwise data and tested for task association (INT vs NoINT) at the group level; components covering rTPJ are reported and illustrated in figures/supplement (satisfies I5 and reporting allowance I6). The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and reports healthy-group effects. No exclusion criteria are met.

The study meets the review topic (fMRI of social/attachment processing) and includes healthy adult participants (women aged 22–45). However, the published analyses and significance testing were conducted using an a priori ROI approach with small-volume correction (SVC), and the paper frames results as ‘regions of interest’ findings. There is no clear report of an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task activation map or whole-brain corrected results independent of ROIs. Because the paper reports only ROI/SVC-based task results rather than an unmasked whole-brain task map, it fails inclusion criterion I5 and must be excluded under E2.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social face-processing task (dynamic angry/neutral faces) and includes a healthy adult control group, the full text reports only between-group (patient vs control) whole-brain contrasts and group comparisons. The paper does not provide a clear, unmasked whole-brain group-level task activation map or main-effect contrast identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. Therefore it violates exclusion criterion E4 (reports only between-group contrasts without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task effect).

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=18, mean age 26) examining perception of different laughter types—a clear social-communication/social-cognition task. The paper presents group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (conjunctions and contrasts) with coordinates and cluster results, and explicitly reports whole-brain and ROI-corrected results in tables/figures. Thus it meets all inclusion requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and does not trigger any exclusion criteria.

This study used task-based fMRI probing social-related processing (self- and other-evaluation of personality traits), includes a healthy adult control group (n=13) whose results are reported separately, and provides whole-brain, voxelwise group-level task activation maps for the control group (one-sample analyses: SELF vs lexical baseline, OTHER vs lexical baseline, conjunction, and SELF vs OTHER) with corrected results and tables of coordinates. The reported results meet acceptable reporting formats (tables/figures and text). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, resting-state-only, between-group-only without healthy-group maps, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion requirements for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study of political (social) attitude processing in healthy adults (ages 21–40). The task involves social cognition (processing politicians’ faces/names using an IAT), and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (congruent vs incongruent, conjunctions, correlational analyses) with coordinates and statistical thresholds. Healthy adult group results are reported separately and not limited to ROIs. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, not between-group-only, participants within 18–65). Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion requirements for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

While this is an fMRI study using a social cognition (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) task and includes a healthy control group, the paper reports primarily between-group contrasts (controls vs high-risk) and diminished activation in high-risk relative to controls. The manuscript does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map (or clearly described within-group whole-brain effects) for the healthy/control group alone. Therefore it violates exclusion criterion E4 (only between-group contrasts reported without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

This is an fMRI study probing emotion processing and mirror neuron responses (social-cognitive constructs: perception/understanding of others/emotion).
