Sample comprises healthy adults (n=19; mean age 27.7, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., untrained>trained whole-brain cluster-corrected results in SMA and IFG) and includes coordinate/cluster information. Although ROI analyses were also conducted, whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy group are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study is an fMRI investigation of empathy for pain (a social/’Perception and Understanding of Others’ task) in healthy adult volunteers. It includes a young healthy subgroup (ages 20–30) satisfying the 18–65 sample requirement, and reports group-level, whole-brain task activation maps (pain>no pain and pain>baseline) with results and statistical maps made available (figures/tables and NeuroVault/supplement). Whole-brain voxelwise analyses (one-sample t-tests and second-level contrasts) are reported rather than only ROI/seed/connectivity results. Therefore it meets the meta-analysis objective and inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=18, mean age 26.4). It uses a social-cognition task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test; Theory of Mind) during task-based fMRI. The paper reports group-level within-group contrasts (ToM > gender) for the healthy/placebo condition and also reports exploratory whole-brain (voxelwise) analyses (P < 0.001 uncorrected) with tables/coordinates, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. All inclusion criteria for the review are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is a task-based fMRI study of multimodal social signal perception (voices and faces) in healthy adults (N=24, mean age 26.6). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (conjunction AV>A AND AV>V), provides voxel coordinates, statistical thresholds, and figures/tables of activation clusters, and applies small-volume correction for a priori ROIs. The task and constructs (social communication, perception of others) clearly map onto the review objective. Healthy adult results are reported separately and directly. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of pragmatic language integration (speaker characteristics with sentence content), which is a social-related processing task (meets I3). It includes a separate healthy adult control group (24 adults, ages 18–39) reported separately (meets I4). The paper reports whole-brain random-effects analyses and within-group contrasts for the control group (tables/figures and text describe clusters and MNI coordinates), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement (I5,I6). The study also reports ROI analyses but importantly provides unmasked whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy/control group, and does not violate any exclusion criteria. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (self- and mother-judgments), conducted in healthy adult participants (Chinese college students) and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (contrasts such as self- vs celebrity and mother- vs celebrity) with tables of activations and coordinates. The task probes perception/understanding of self and others (social-related processing). Whole-brain results are reported and described in the text/tables (Tables 2–3, figures), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria for the review are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is a task-based dual-fMRI hyperscanning study of social interaction (cooperation/competition) in healthy adults (38 participants, mean age 22.4), meeting the sample requirement. The study uses fMRI during an explicit social-related task and reports group-level, whole-brain spatial maps from group-ICA that are related to task conditions via regression and group-level comparisons (paired t-tests), providing whole-brain task-evoked evidence. Results are presented as spatial component maps and condition-related statistics, and group-level effects for healthy participants are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-healthy sample) are violated.

While this fMRI study uses a social (mentalizing) task and includes a healthy adult control group (I3, I4), the paper does not report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. The manuscript’s whole-brain analysis is reported only as a between-group contrast (Controls > ASC) and the within-group findings are reported primarily via ROI analyses. Therefore it lacks a clearly identified healthy-group whole-brain task effect, violating inclusion criterion I5 and falling under exclusion criterion E4.

This fMRI study investigates perception and understanding of others’ actions (anticipation from opponent body kinematics), which falls under social-related processing. Participants are healthy adult badminton players (novice to international), meeting the sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain (random-effects) voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., shots–mctrl, thresholded at P<0.05 FWE) with coordinates and figures, and further tables of peak voxels—fulfilling whole-brain reporting requirements. Therefore it satisfies the fMRI social-task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain result inclusion criteria.

This study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=23, ages 19–32) while they read a narrative and provided suspense ratings. The task probes social-cognitive processes (mentalizing/theory-of-mind and inference about characters), and the authors explicitly interpret activations as related to social cognition (MFC, TPJ). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (second-level random effects SPM results) are reported with cluster- and ROI-corrected statistics and tables/figures of coordinates. Thus the paper provides whole-brain task-evoked maps from a healthy adult sample for a social-related process (perception/understanding of others).

While the study is an fMRI investigation of social gaze processing in a sample of healthy adult participants (meets the review aim and sample criteria), all reported neuroimaging results are ROI-based (amygdala and inferior occipital gyrus) with statistical inference reported FWE-corrected within those ROIs. The paper does not present or describe an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map or whole-brain coordinate tables for the healthy/control group. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain evidence and meets exclusion criterion E2 (ROI-only results).

Although this is an fMRI study of face processing (a social perception task) and includes a healthy adult control group, the neuroimaging analyses are conducted as region-of-interest (individual right FFA) analyses rather than reporting group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy/control group. The paper localizes individual FFAs and extracts ROI beta weights/amplitudes for between-group and within-group comparisons; no unmasked, group-level whole-brain activation map for the healthy group is provided. Therefore it does not meet the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task effects and must be excluded.

This fMRI study tested voice processing—a social-perception task—using whole-brain analyses and reports clear group-level results for a healthy adult control group. The paper includes eight healthy adult volunteers (ages reported, adult range), and reports random-effect, whole-brain activation for the control group (voice vs. non-voice, P < 0.001 corrected) with figures/tables described in the text and supplementary materials. Although the study also includes an autism clinical group, results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, missing healthy-group whole-brain maps, or non-empirical paper) apply. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study that explicitly probes social-emotional processing (images of group interactions vs individuals) and instructs participants to imagine themselves in the scenarios, matching the social-related constructs. A healthy control group of adults (mean age 32.4) is reported separately. The paper presents group-level, voxelwise task activation results for the control group (main effects and contrasts with reported MNI coordinates and corrected statistical thresholds), satisfying the whole-brain reporting requirement. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

The study uses task-based fMRI of social processing with a healthy adult control group (meets I3 and I4), but the full text does not report a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The paper’s whole-brain searchlight results are reported for the combined sample (all participants) and ROI-based analyses are reported separately by group, but I could not find an unmasked, voxelwise whole-brain map/statistical contrast reported specifically for the healthy/control group (NT). Because the review requires a healthy-group whole-brain task effect, this study fails I5 and therefore must be excluded under E4.

This is an empirical fMRI study employing a social-perception task (face discrimination) with intranasal oxytocin. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=14; ages ~24) and results for controls are reported separately (ROI and group-specific contrasts). The paper reports group-level voxelwise whole-brain analyses (faces>houses) for the whole sample and follow-up group-level analyses for each group, including coordinates and SVC-corrected clusters identified for the neurotypical control group. Whole-brain results are reported in tables/figures with coordinates. Although some effects used small-volume correction within a face-processing mask, group-level voxelwise task-evoked maps/coordinates for the healthy/control group are clearly presented, satisfying inclusion criteria.

This study reports an fMRI task probing social perception (observation of cooperative vs noncooperative interactions), includes a clearly reported healthy adult control group (n=19) analyzed separately, and provides whole-brain, voxelwise group-level task contrasts for the healthy controls (e.g., C+ > C–; FDR- and FWE-corrected results, MNI coordinates reported). The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others), and whole-brain healthy-group activation maps/contrasts are explicitly described. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, resting-state-only, or absence of healthy-group whole-brain task maps) apply. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study that measured emotion processing and theory-of-mind tasks using faces/eyes (social-related tasks) and reports group-level activation maps for healthy adult controls (N=14). Whole-brain voxelwise analyses are presented (within-group contrasts EMOTION–GENDER with thresholding) with figures and supplementary tables describing healthy-group activations. Healthy participants are adults within the 18–65 range and their results are reported separately from patient and sibling groups. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, and includes unmasked healthy-group task effects).

This study uses task-based fMRI to examine personal prayer vs secular controls, which probes social-cognitive processing (theory-of-mind) and thus meets the social-related task requirement. The sample consists of 20 healthy adult participants (ages 21–32). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts thresholded (p < 0.05 FDR) and provides tables of coordinates and figures. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6. No exclusion criteria (E2–E6) are triggered: results are not limited to ROIs, are task-evoked (not only connectivity/resting-state), and report healthy adult whole-brain effects.

This study used task-based fMRI with a social contingency (pseudo-interactive joke) paradigm and includes a healthy neurotypical adult control group; however, the paper reports only a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis focused on the anterior rostral MPFC and explicitly states that whole-brain and functional connectivity analyses could not be conducted due to signal loss. No group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation maps for the healthy/control group are reported. Therefore it fails the whole-brain evidence requirement for inclusion.

This is an empirical event-related fMRI study in healthy adults (n=34, ages 20–28) using a theory-of-mind/false-belief social task (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked activation maps and coordinates (random-effects analysis, SPM2; figures and Table 1), and describes thresholds and ROIs; results are clearly from the healthy participant group. The study therefore meets the meta-analysis requirements for fMRI during social-related tasks, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state only, between-group-only contrasts, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated.

This study reports an fMRI mentalizing paradigm (social-cognitive task) and includes an age- and IQ-matched healthy adult control group (18 adults) alongside an autism spectrum group. The abstract and results describe task-evoked brain activations (e.g., medial prefrontal cortex and temporoparietal junction) tied to the mentalizing paradigm, indicating voxelwise whole-brain fMRI analyses. Thus the paper meets the review’s focus on social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults and provides group-level activation results for the control group (reported in main text/figures). Therefore it satisfies the inclusion requirements for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level results.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social-perception task and includes a healthy adult control group (meeting I3 and I4), the full text presents seed-based/background (intrinsic) connectivity analyses and between-group connectivity contrasts. It does not report any group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group (unmasked task activation map or coordinates thereof) required by inclusion criterion I5. Therefore it falls under exclusion criterion E3 (reports only seed-based/background connectivity without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map).

This is an fMRI study of social touch in healthy adult humans (40 heterosexual males, mean age 25.8). It uses a task manipulating perceived toucher (female vs male) and reports task-evoked, group-level whole-brain voxelwise activation maps and contrasts (e.g., touch vs close, Female TouchOXT>Female TouchPLC) with whole-brain cluster coordinates and family-wise error-corrected results. Behavioral and neural results are reported for the healthy sample separately. The study therefore meets the review objective and satisfies inclusion criteria for task-based social processing fMRI in healthy adults without violating exclusion criteria.

The study uses fMRI during a social task in healthy adults (male participants) and thus meets I3 and I4. However, the full-text describes between-group comparisons (low fear scorers vs normal fear scorers) and reports reduced activation in specific regions and connectivity differences. The manuscript summary does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for a healthy/control group (e.g., main effect or within-group whole-brain contrast for the healthy sample as a whole). Because only subgroup between-group contrasts and connectivity analyses are described, this violates the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task effect (I5) and falls under exclusion criterion E4.

This study used task-based fMRI during face perception (socially relevant stimuli), includes a healthy adult control group (n=7, mean age 30 within 18–65), and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (within-group deactivation maps for task vs. rest and group comparisons) with cluster-correction described. Healthy-control results are reported separately (within-group analysis and comparisons), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps or descriptions of them.

This fMRI study used a social-related task (viewing others performing body-checking and imagining oneself doing the actions), engaging self- and other-related/social-cognitive processing. It includes a healthy control group of adults (age-matched females; overall sample age range 17–34) and reports group-level, whole-brain task activation maps and coordinates for the healthy control group (figures and Table 2). Whole-brain analyses (voxelwise/cluster-level) are described and healthy-group activation is clearly reported. Therefore the study meets the review’s criteria for task domain (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), whole-brain healthy-group results (I5), and acceptable reporting of whole-brain results (I6).

The provided full-text excerpt contains stimulus materials and the paper metadata (title, authors, journal) that strongly imply an fMRI study of social/irony processing. However, the excerpt does not include any methodological details: no participant demographics or ages to confirm a healthy adult sample (I4 cannot be verified), and no group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps or reported whole-brain results (I5/I6 cannot be verified). Because the review requires explicit reporting of a healthy adult group and whole-brain activation results, and these crucial elements are not present in the supplied content, the study cannot be confirmed to meet all inclusion criteria and must be excluded.

This study reports task-based fMRI during social-related processing (self and other reflection), in a healthy adult sample (n=22, mean age 37.4). Group-level whole-brain (cortical surface/voxelwise) analyses for the SR > AL contrast are reported (figures and cluster-corrected results and tables), and task-evoked activation maps and coordinates are clearly described for the healthy group. Resting-state analyses are secondary but do not replace the reported whole-brain task activations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.
Screening failed:

This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy young adults using a social attribution task (perception of human-like interactions among shapes), directly addressing social-related processing. The abstract and reported activations (FFA, amygdala, medial prefrontal cortex, STS, etc.) indicate group-level task-evoked whole-brain activation results for the healthy sample. The sample is healthy adults, and whole-brain voxelwise activations are described (satisfying acceptability of coordinate/figure reporting). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply. Therefore the study meets the review inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of charitable donation decisions (social/moral behavior) in healthy adults. The task probes social-related constructs (attachment, moral decision-making, affiliation) using task-evoked fMRI. The sample comprises 19 healthy adults (age range fits 18–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects voxelwise analyses (one-sample t tests on first-level contrast images) with whole-brain contrasts and coordinates reported in main/supplementary materials. Results include standard whole-brain activation maps and tables of coordinates for contrasts of interest. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adult empirical fMRI data). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Insufficient information in the provided full text to confirm that the paper reports a healthy adult group with a clearly identified, group-level whole-brain task-evoked activation map. The study title and focus (schizophrenia out-patients) suggest emphasis on patient vs control comparisons and it likely reports between-group contrasts without an unmasked healthy-group task effect. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria I4/I5 and matches exclusion criterion E4.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social perception (eye-gaze intention processing), directly addressing social-related processing. The paper reports results for a neurologically normal (control) group separately (n=9, mean age 23.4, range 15.5–32.4) and provides group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise statistical maps and coordinate tables and figures (random-effects analyses, Table 1, and activation maps for the control group). Whole-brain contrasts (incongruent > congruent) for the healthy/control group are explicitly reported. Therefore it meets the fMRI social-task requirement, has a healthy control group with reported group-level results, and provides whole-brain evidence in figures/tables. (Note: control group includes one participant aged 15.5, but group-level healthy adult results are presented and the majority of the group falls within 18–65.)

The study uses task-based fMRI to probe social-related processing (viewing and emotional evaluation of others’ faces—political candidates), meeting the review’s social processing scope. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=20; ages mean ~35) within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation maps and contrasts (faces vs rest; candidate pairwise contrasts; group comparisons), with thresholded Z maps, tables of coordinates, and figures—satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Results are clearly from healthy adult groups and not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, age out of range, non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study should be included.

This empirical fMRI study used a social cognition (virtual reality face-to-face) task and acquired whole-brain BOLD data. It included a healthy adult control group (n=14; ages matched to 18–45 sample) reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts for the healthy/control group (within-group Emotion vs Control maps, figures and tables of coordinates) using voxelwise thresholding. Reporting of coordinates and figures satisfies acceptable whole-brain result reporting. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=20 analyzed; mean age 20.65) that investigates event simulation including social situations and social-cognition processes (mentions theory of mind, trait inference; 41/96 stimuli depict social interactions). The study reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Imp–Con, Exp–Imp, Ftr–Exp) using SPM random-effects analyses with whole-brain cluster correction and peak coordinates reported; results are clearly from the healthy/control sample. Whole-brain results are presented in text, figures, and coordinate tables. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task activation reporting.

This paper reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adults (n=21) using an interactive gaze-based social task (joint attention), which is directly relevant to social processing. Group-level, whole-brain task-evoked results are reported: differential increases in MPFC, PCC, anterior temporal poles and fronto-parietal regions (voxel-level correction noted), indicating unmasked healthy-group activations. The sample is within the adult age range and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is empirical and provides whole-brain activation findings for social-cognitive conditions, meeting the review objective.

This fMRI study used a face identity discrimination task (social perception of others) and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise activation maps. It includes a healthy adult control group (N=17, mean age ~31) with results for that group reported separately and displayed as mean z-score images and voxelwise contrasts corrected for multiple comparisons. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI, a healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level task activation reporting.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related task (dynamic virtual characters with direct vs averted gaze) that probes social cognition/eye-contact processing, satisfying I3. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=16) reported separately from the PTSD group, satisfying I4. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task-evoked analyses for the control group (full-factorial and within-group contrasts; tables/figures of whole-brain results are provided), satisfying I5 and I6. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age outside 18–65, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all required inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social/emotional task (facial affect matching), includes a healthy adult control group (n=12; ages ~32) reported separately, and reports group-level whole-brain task activation results for the healthy group (within-group Emotion Match > Shape Match contrasts, tables and figures). Whole-brain random-effects analyses and within-group maps for healthy participants are clearly presented, satisfying reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria are met.

The study reports task-based fMRI during social-related processing (facial emotion recognition and non-emotional face judgments), fulfilling social cognition construct. It includes a healthy adult control group (community controls aged 18–65) with results reported separately. The paper provides group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and between- and within-group whole-brain analyses (with tables and figures describing control within-group activations and contrasts), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Results for controls are clearly described in text, tables, and figures (including within-group activation maps and contrasts), meeting the reporting criterion. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults, is empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study reports task-based fMRI during incidental priming of participants’ own promotion/prevention goals — a social-cognitive/self-related processing task (fits social-related constructs such as Perception and Understanding of Self). The sample consists of 16 participants with no mention of clinical groups, indicating a healthy adult group is analyzed separately. The paper describes task-related cortical activation and identifies specific prefrontal regions associated with promotion goal priming and correlations with individual differences, consistent with reporting group-level whole-brain task-evoked activations rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. There is no indication of exclusionary issues (ROI-only analyses, connectivity-only, between-group-only effects, non-adult sample, or non-empirical paper). Confidence is moderated because the provided excerpt does not explicitly list participant ages or verbatim ‘whole-brain voxelwise’ terminology, but the reported cortical activations in a J. Cogn. Neurosci. empirical fMRI study support inclusion.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of a social stimulus (direct vs averted gaze) and includes a healthy adult control group (I3, I4), the paper reports only seed-based psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity results rather than an unambiguous, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group. The reported whole-brain analyses refer to PPI (connectivity) contrasts and between-group connectivity comparisons; no healthy-group whole-brain task activation map (main effect or within-group task contrast of activation) is clearly presented. This matches exclusion criterion E3 (studies reporting only seed-based/effective connectivity without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map). Therefore the study must be excluded from the meta-analysis.

This study used task-based fMRI with social stimuli (emotional faces) and included a healthy adult control group, but the reported group-level fMRI results are restricted to an a priori amygdala ROI (results corrected within the amygdala). The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map or whole-brain coordinates clearly identified for the healthy/control group. Because the meta-analysis requires at least one healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map and studies reporting only ROI analyses without whole-brain results must be excluded, this study does not meet the necessary whole-brain reporting criterion.

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants during a social task (viewing emotional faces), the reported neuroimaging results are primarily ROI analyses (FFA and amygdala percent signal change) and seed-based psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity analyses. The paper does not present an unambiguous group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation map (e.g., main effect of faces or angry>neutral) for the healthy/control group that would satisfy I5. Instead, the main voxelwise results are seed-based connectivity interactions (PPI) and between-group (sex-by-stress) interaction effects. Therefore it violates exclusion criteria for reporting only seed-based connectivity/effective connectivity without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task activation map, and for reporting primarily between-group interactions without an unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect.

This fMRI study used whole-brain, voxelwise analysis of BOLD responses while healthy adult participants (10 right-handed males, ages within 18–65) viewed funny vs. non-funny cartoons, a task involving social-cognitive processing (humor appreciation/social communication and understanding of others). Group-level whole-brain results are reported (Talairach coordinates, cluster statistics, p-values, table and figure), satisfying the reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, not between-group-only, and participants are healthy adults). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

The study is an fMRI investigation of memory for emotional faces, which is a social-related task (perception and understanding of others). Participants are healthy adults (N=35, mean age 29). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects ANCOVA, FDR<.05) with Talairach coordinates and whole-brain contrasts (emotion main effect, angry>neutral, load contrasts) clearly reported. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The study uses fMRI during a social-related task (observation of goal-directed hand actions probing the mirror neuron system), addressing perception/understanding of others. The sample consists of healthy adult college students (n=37) analyzed as ALEX and non-ALEX healthy groups. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain one-sample task effects for each healthy group and a conjunction, with voxelwise statistical maps and tables of coordinates. Reporting is clear and includes whole-brain results. Therefore it satisfies the review inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

This is an event-related fMRI study of agency attribution (social cognition/Perception and Understanding of Others) using animated stimuli to evoke intentionality. Participants were healthy adults (n=12, mean age 25.2), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses (contrasts High>Low and Low>High) with reported activated regions and statistical thresholds (p<0.001 uncorrected). Whole-brain task-evoked results are clearly described in the text and figures. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults and does not violate exclusion criteria.

The study used task-based fMRI to measure brain responses during perception of biological motion, a social-related process (meets I3). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15, mean age ~25), reported separately (meets I4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation maps/contrasts for the control group (biological motion vs scrambled) with coordinate tables and figures (meets I5 and I6). The analyses include whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only), and healthy-group effects are clearly presented, so no exclusion criteria are triggered. Therefore the study should be included.

This study used task-based fMRI to investigate vicarious somatosensory responses during observation of touch, which addresses social perception/understanding of others (social-related processing). The sample consisted of healthy adult participants (N=22, analyzed N=20; ages 23–39) meeting the age range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses with FWE-corrected results and coordinates (tables/figures) for the healthy participant group. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study of empathy for others' pain (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=13; ages mean 33) reported separately from the congenital insensitivity to pain patients. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task contrasts and tables of coordinates and figures for the control group (within-group activations such as AI, aMCC, insula, etc.), satisfying whole-brain voxelwise reporting. Results are not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and healthy-group effects are clearly identified. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This study does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria. It uses resting-state functional connectivity (seed-based fcMRI) rather than task-based fMRI during a social-related task, and therefore does not provide task-evoked whole-brain activation maps for a healthy adult group. Participants are adolescents (ages 11–18), so there is no healthy adult sample within the required 18–65 age range. Consequently it violates criteria disallowing resting-state/seed-based-only studies and the age-range requirement.

This study reports fMRI data collected during an interactive social decision-making (modified prisoner’s dilemma) task, includes a healthy control group of adults (ages 23–45) with results reported separately, and presents group-level whole-brain task activation analyses (within-group HC contrasts, tables/figures, cluster-level corrected maps). Whole-brain results for the healthy group are clearly described and satisfy the meta-analysis reporting requirements.

The study used fMRI during a social task (facial emotion recognition) in healthy adult participants; however, the paper reports whole-brain results only as between-group contrasts (LDA > HDA and HDA > LDA). It does not present an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map (e.g., Emo_Emo > Neu_Age) clearly identified as coming from a healthy/control group independent of subgroup comparisons. Therefore it meets exclusion criterion E4 (only between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

Although this study uses fMRI during a social task (gaze processing) and reports whole-brain, group-level task activation maps for the typically developing (control) group, it does not meet the review’s age-sample requirement. The reported control sample is described as “adolescents and adults” with an age range of 16.1–42.4 years, i.e., it includes participants under 18 and the authors did not report a separate healthy adult (18–65) subgroup. Therefore the study violates the age inclusion requirement and must be excluded (E5).

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related body perception task probing perception/understanding of self and others. The sample comprises healthy adults (N=30, mean age 26, 15 males/15 females) meeting the age/sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (e.g., own body > scrambled, same-sex other > scrambled, opposite-sex other > scrambled), thresholded and cluster-corrected, with tables/figures and coordinate reporting. Results for the healthy control participants are reported separately for males and females and in combined analyses, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, age out of range, or missing healthy-group whole-brain maps) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This empirical fMRI study examines perception/understanding of others by comparing goal-directed (sports-related) versus non-goal-directed biological motion, a social-related task. Participants are healthy adults (mean age 29.4), and group-level whole-brain task contrasts (BR minus BU) are reported with voxelwise statistics and peak coordinates. Results include whole-brain corrected thresholds and uncorrected a priori ROIs, fulfilling reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI study of social/emotional processing (perception of fearful vs neutral body gestures), satisfying the social-related task requirement. The paper includes a healthy adult control group (adult males) reported separately and compared to the ASD group. The manuscript reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses for controls (contrasts, conjunction analyses, thresholded statistical maps, tables of coordinates and figures), providing the required whole-brain task-evoked results. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6. Confidence is high though exact control age range is not explicitly quoted in the excerpt; the text indicates adult controls and notes groups did not differ on age, supporting eligibility.

The study recruited only depressed mothers of psychiatrically ill children (N=19) and reports whole-brain task activation maps for that clinical group only. The review requires at least one group of healthy adult participants and/or whole-brain task maps from a healthy/control group. Because no healthy adult group is analyzed or reported separately, the study does not meet the sample requirement (I4) and lacks the required healthy-group whole-brain task effect (I5). Therefore it must be excluded from the meta-analysis.

The study uses task-based fMRI during an explicit social task (imitate/observe emotional faces), includes a healthy adult group (ages 18–55) reported separately within the sample, and reports second-level, whole-brain group analyses (t-maps/contrast maps) derived from the task. The methods state that second-level analyses were run separately by site and group, and the manuscript presents whole-brain group-level maps and contrasts (e.g., imitate > observe) used in the clustering and group analyses. These whole-brain task-evoked results are clearly described and meet the reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, out-of-age-range, or non-empirical) apply.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI with social stimuli and includes a healthy (neurotypical) adult control group, the full text does not present a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The manuscript reports whole-brain results collapsed across groups and a between-group contrast (NT > ASD), but no unmasked NT-only whole-brain task map is provided in the text. Per exclusion criterion E4, studies that report only between-group contrasts or lack an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect must be excluded.

This is an event-related fMRI study of evaluative judgments (self-referential/social cognition/theory of mind), which is a social-related task. The paper includes a healthy adult control group (mean age ~26.4, within 18–65) reported separately. The authors present whole-brain, group-level task activation maps and coordinate tables for the control group (figures and Table 3) using voxelwise analyses corrected for multiple comparisons. Reporting includes within-group contrasts for controls (evaluative judgment vs. semantic retrieval), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study uses fMRI during a social (multi-round trust game) task and includes a healthy adult control group (20 males, age 18–50), satisfying I3 and I4. However, the paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group. The only whole-brain analyses presented are exploratory voxel-wise between-group contrasts (control > patient), not a within-group healthy-task effect. Therefore it violates exclusion criterion E4 (only between-group contrasts without an accompanying unmasked healthy-group whole-brain task effect).

The study used task-based fMRI (passive viewing of natural movies) and explicitly modeled responses to social communication and many object/action categories, reporting voxelwise encoding models and group-level cortical maps across healthy adult participants. Subjects were healthy adults (mean age ~26.7). The analyses are whole-brain voxelwise (voxelwise encoding models, variance-partitioning, and projections onto cortical surfaces) and group-level results are reported/aggregated across subjects. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for fMRI during social-related processing, healthy adult sample, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses, and acceptable reporting (tables/figures/text).

The paper includes an fMRI subsample of 25 female patients with social anxiety disorder and reports correlations between OXTR methylation and amygdala responsiveness within that patient group using an ROI analysis of the bilateral amygdala. It does not report a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked statistical map for a healthy/control group. Therefore it fails the requirement for a healthy adult whole-brain task activation map and reports ROI-only fMRI results for the relevant analyses. Exclusion criteria applied: E2 (only ROI analyses with no whole-brain results) and E4 (no accompanying unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect reported).

Although this fMRI study used a social-related simulation task (empathy for pain) and included a healthy adult control group reported separately (satisfying I3 and I4), the paper does not provide an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. Whole-brain results are reported for the full sample (HC + SZ) and no HC-only whole-brain contrasts/maps are presented. Primary neuroimaging inferences rely on ROI analyses and combined-group whole-brain ANOVA; thus the study lacks the required healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map. This violates exclusion criterion E4 (no accompanying unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

This fMRI study used a task (listening to and rating artistic vs. popular music) that elicited and analyzed social-cognition/ToM and empathy-related activations. Authors explicitly report greater recruitment of default mode network/ToM and cognitive-empathy regions (arMFC, PCC/PC, TP, hippocampus) for artistic music and interpret these as social-cognitive/empathic processing. The sample is healthy adults (male, 18–24), and group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation results are reported with coordinates/tables and cluster-level corrections. Thus the paper provides whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps relevant to social-related processing and satisfies the review’s inclusion criteria.

This study is ineligible for the meta-analysis because it does not use task-based fMRI in healthy adults. It reports resting-state functional connectivity in a clinical sample (male adults with ASD) and examines effects of endogenous and exogenous oxytocin. There is no healthy/control group whole-brain task-evoked activation map: the MRI data are resting-state (intrinsic connectivity) rather than task-evoked, and results pertain to the ASD group; no separate healthy adult group results are reported. Therefore it matches the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only resting-state/seed-based connectivity without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation.

This is an empirical fMRI study in a healthy adult sample (male participants aged 19–60) using a deception task that probes social-cognitive processes (deception/manipulation involves perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (lie > truth and truth > lie) with statistical maps, thresholding details, tables of activations and figures, and describes small-volume corrections and exploratory whole-brain analyses. All inclusion criteria for the review are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a facial emotion discrimination task (socially relevant processing of others’ emotional expressions). Participants are healthy adults aged 19–35 with a clearly defined normal control (NC) group reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task activation results (cluster tables and FWE-corrected maps) for within-group contrasts and condition effects in the NC as well as between-group contrasts; ROI results are supplementary but whole-brain voxelwise results for the healthy control group are clearly described. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, includes healthy adult subgroup, empirical fMRI task data).

This paper is a tutorial/methods/review article about intersubject correlation (ISC) analysis and related techniques. It does not report original empirical fMRI data from participants, does not describe a specific social-task experiment with a healthy adult sample, and does not present any group-level, whole-brain task activation maps for a healthy/control group. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring original fMRI task data and whole-brain results. Excluded under E6 (non-empirical paper without original fMRI data in healthy adults).

The study exclusively reports data from patients with bipolar disorder (no healthy control group is included or reported). Although it uses whole-brain fMRI during a social-related task (facial emotion/gender discrimination), it does not provide any group-level whole-brain task-evoked map for a healthy adult sample. Therefore it fails inclusion criterion I4 (healthy adult group) and must be excluded under E4 (no accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

This fMRI study investigates social-related processing (cognitive and emotional empathy) using the Multifaceted Empathy Test, satisfying the social-task requirement. The sample includes healthy adult control participants reported separately from the BPD group (female controls, presumably adults within 18–65), meeting the sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation results for the healthy/control group (main effects and within-group contrasts are presented in tables and figures with MNI coordinates), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results are reported as coordinates/tables and described in the text. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only reporting, connectivity-only, or lack of healthy-group whole-brain maps) are violated.

The study used fMRI and included a healthy adult control group and reported whole-brain, group-level activation maps for the control group (so I4, I5, I6 are satisfied). However, the experimental task was a continuous performance task with monetary reward (reward processing), not a social-related task (no social interaction/communication or perception-of-others paradigm). Thus it fails inclusion criterion I3 (social-related task) required by the review objective. No exclusion criteria E2–E6 directly apply.

This fMRI study uses a social-related task (participant-generated autobiographical social situations and negative self-beliefs) addressing perception/understanding of self and social processing. The sample is healthy adults (N=35, age range 22.6–55.4), meeting the 18–65 requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise contrasts (react vs neutral; reappraisal vs react; acceptance vs react; direct contrasts) with tables/figures and ROI analyses; whole-brain results and coordinates are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-eligible age range) apply. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

The study used fMRI during a social-related task (facial emotion processing) and reports group-level whole-brain task activation analyses for the healthy control group (paired t-tests, one-sample t-tests; threshold p<0.05 FWE corrected). Healthy control results are reported separately from the clinical group. Although the sample age range includes 16–40 years (so some participants may be under 18), the healthy group is reported as a distinct control group within the adult range (up to 40). Thus the paper meets the review’s criteria for fMRI social-task, healthy adult controls, and whole-brain healthy-group results; confidence tempered slightly by the reported lower bound of the overall sample age range.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (implicit interpersonal space/affiliation) in healthy adult participants (male, ages 19–30). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses (main effects and interactions; random-effects GLM with cluster correction) and presents neuroimaging results in the text/figures, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. The sample is within the 18–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI- or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria for the review are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

The study uses fMRI during a social perception task and includes a healthy adult control group, but the full text reports whole-brain analyses only as between-group contrasts (patients vs. controls) and ROI follow-ups. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain task activation map or group-level whole-brain contrast coming solely from the healthy/control group (e.g., a main effect or within-group HC contrast) that is clearly identified and reported. Therefore it violates exclusion criterion E4 (only between-group contrasts reported without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task effect).

Although the study uses fMRI during face processing (a social-related task), the sample consists entirely of individuals with chronic traumatic brain injury (no healthy adult/control group reported separately). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criterion I4 (at least one healthy adult group). Because no unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task activation map is provided, it fails the review’s requirement for healthy-group whole-brain results. Exclusion is based on the absence of a healthy adult whole-brain task effect.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 21.6) investigating social cognition (emotion identification and attribution — perception and understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., How>Why, Why>How) with FDR-corrected statistical maps and tables of coordinates. Whole-brain results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (three cultural groups, n=78, ages within 18–65) that used a social cognition task (reading personal narratives involving others and moral/protected values). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., stories vs rest; protected-value stories vs non-protected) with cluster correction and describes whole-brain results in the text and figures. Thus it meets the fMRI social task requirement, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting (including coordinates/figures). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) are violated.

This study used task-based fMRI during social judgement tasks (approachability/intelligence) in healthy adult participants, reporting separate healthy control group results. Group-level whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (social > gender) for healthy males and females are reported, with peak coordinates, thresholding, and figures/tables described. Thus it meets I3 (fMRI social task), I4 (healthy adult group reported separately), I5 (whole-brain group-level voxelwise maps reported), and I6 (results presented in figures/coordinates). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an event-related fMRI study of facial emotion processing (social perception/understanding of others), involving an implicit social task. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=9, mean age 27±5) reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise activation maps and analyses for the control group (figures, tables, and supplementary materials) using voxel- and cluster-wise thresholding. Reporting of whole-brain results in tables/figures satisfies acceptable formats. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state-only, only between-group without healthy-group maps, age outside 18–65, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication (L2 communication vs description), directly addressing social-related processing. The sample comprises 30 healthy adult native Japanese speakers (L2 learners), satisfying the healthy adult sample requirement. The paper reports group-level brain activations (e.g., left posterior supramarginal gyrus, left MTG, OFC/insula) clearly described as task-evoked effects for the healthy participant group, indicating whole-brain voxelwise results (reported in text/figures/tables). Reporting meets the allowance for coordinate/figure/table presentation. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages, or only between-group contrasts) appear to apply. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

This fMRI study investigates third-party punishment, a social cognitive task involving mentalizing and judgment about others (social processing). It reports data from 26 healthy adult participants (mean age 26) within the 18–65 range. The authors performed whole-brain, group-level GLM analyses and report whole-brain task-evoked activations (Decision Phase: Experimental > Control) with FDR-corrected thresholds and coordinate tables/figures, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain evidence. Results are clearly described for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria apply.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social cognition (trustworthiness judgments) and includes a healthy adult control group (I3, I4), the paper reports ROI-based analyses of percent signal change and condition-by-group ANOVAs without presenting any group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy/control group. No unmasked whole-brain healthy-group activation maps or coordinate tables from whole-brain contrasts are provided in the full text. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain evidence (I5) and meets exclusion criterion E2 (ROI-only results).

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of a social paradigm (empathy-for-pain) and includes a healthy adult control group, the full text does not clearly report a within-control-group, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map that is unambiguously identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The reported whole-brain analyses appear to focus on alexithymia-based subgroups and group comparisons, and the text describes a between-group contrast (control vs. autism) but does not present an unmasked, whole-brain control-group task effect. Because the review requires at least one clearly reported whole-brain healthy-group task map, this study fails inclusion criterion I5 and therefore must be excluded under E4 (reports only between-group contrasts/subgroup analyses without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

This is an fMRI study using a social-affective task (video clips of others in distress; SoVT) and tests emotion regulation strategies (Compassion, Reappraisal), directly addressing social-related processing (affiliation/compassion, perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy adult long-term meditators (ages 45–62), satisfying age and healthy-sample requirements. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., Compassion > Watch-Negative, Reappraisal > Watch-Negative) with cluster-level FWE correction and provides tables/figures of whole-brain results. Thus it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

Although the study involves healthy adult participants (mothers aged 21–42) and uses fMRI in the context of a social/affiliation task (mothers viewing films of infants), it does not report any group-level, whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise activation maps for the healthy group. The fMRI analyses reported focus on task-independent (resting-state) intrinsic connectivity of a medial amygdala network and seed-based correlations, and PET [11C]raclopride measures of dopamine. Because only resting-state/seed-based connectivity and PET-derived effects are reported without an accompanying whole-brain task activation map, the study violates exclusion criterion E3.

This is an fMRI study using a social task (cyberball) examining social exclusion/inclusion (I3). The sample includes a healthy adult control group (20 female HCs; adults) reported separately from the BPD group (I4). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (flexible factorial, main effects and interactions) and refers to t-contrasts reported in the Supplementary Data (Supplementary Table S4), and presents group- and condition-level whole-brain results and post-hoc within-group findings for HCs (I5, I6). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only without healthy-group maps, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social processes (ToM and empathy) and includes a healthy control group, the reported results focus on between-group contrasts and conjunctions showing diagnosis effects. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (e.g., a within-group main effect or healthy-group contrast). Therefore it fails the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map and meets exclusion criterion E4.

Although this is an fMRI study of audiovisual speech (a form of social communication) including a healthy adult control group, the paper does not present a whole-brain, group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. The reported whole-brain main effect of audiovisual congruency is across combined participants and the paper focuses on group-by-congruency interactions; no unmasked, healthy-group whole-brain task contrast (or map) is reported. This violates the requirement for healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked results. Inclusion criteria I3 and I4 are met, but exclusion criterion E4 applies.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social cognition task (Theory of Mind; false-belief vs false-photo), satisfying the social-related task requirement. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=25) aged 18–59, meeting the 18–65 criterion. The authors report whole-brain, group-level task activation contrasts (FB > FP) and explicitly state they derived functional ROIs/masks from the control group data (i.e., a control-group FB>FP map), with FWE-corrected results and figures/tables referenced; thus whole-brain healthy-group task effects are available. Results are reported in the main text and supplemental materials. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-only, only between-group contrasts without healthy-group task map, out-of-age-range, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social processing (fearful faces with gaze manipulation), includes a clearly defined healthy adult control group (n=22, ages within 18–65) with results reported separately, and presents group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (within-group contrasts for controls and between-group comparisons) with corrected statistical maps. Thus it meets the meta-analysis requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This study used task-based fMRI of social-related processing (mothers viewing their own vs. other children and child behaviors), included healthy adult participants (mothers, ages implied within 18–65 and analyzed as a single adult group), and reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (whole-brain contrasts, figures, and coordinate-based results derived from whole-brain analysis). Reporting of results in figures/tables and text meets acceptable reporting formats. Therefore it satisfies I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This article is a Personal View / review paper discussing mirror neuron dysfunction in autism spectrum disorders and summarizes evidence from fMRI, TMS, and EEG. It does not report original empirical fMRI data from healthy adult participants nor present any group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps for a healthy/control group. Therefore it fails the requirement for original whole-brain task activation data. It is a non-empirical paper rather than an fMRI study meeting inclusion criteria.

The study uses fMRI in healthy adults and reports whole-brain task-evoked analyses (coordinates and cluster-corrected maps) and includes a healthy adult group (younger group age 19–28), satisfying I4, I5, and I6. However, the experimental task is a word/pseudoword repetition task focused on speech production and motor/phonological processes rather than a social-processing or social-communication task. Although the introduction discusses social aspects of imitation, the task itself does not involve social interaction, affiliation/attachment, perception of others, or explicit social communication paradigms. Therefore it does not meet the required social-related task inclusion criterion (I3) and must be excluded.

This empirical fMRI study used a social cognition (theory-of-mind) task and reports task-evoked, group-level whole-brain analyses for a healthy adult control group (within-group contrasts and coordinates/tables). The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=12, mean age 24.8) reported separately from the clinical group. Whole-brain results for the control group are presented (figures and coordinate tables) with appropriate statistical thresholds. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age outside range, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing (attentional orienting to eye gaze vs arrows with social voice vs tone contexts) in healthy adults (n=22, mean age ~23). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation analyses (main effects and interactions) with appropriate statistical thresholds and tables/figures, and also provides ROI/small-volume correction results. All relevant inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social gaze processing using a task with virtual characters (social-related processing). The sample is healthy adults (N=30 after exclusions; ages 19–41). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (second-level flexible factorial contrasts; cluster-forming threshold p<0.001 and FWE cluster correction) with reported coordinates and figures. Whole-brain results are clearly described for the healthy participant group. Although the paper also reports PPI connectivity, it additionally provides unmasked whole-brain task activation maps and coordinate tables. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This empirical fMRI study includes a social decision-making (altruism) task probing perceptions of others’ outcomes and focus on a partner’s feelings – clearly a social-related construct. Participants are healthy adults (altruism N=55, subset N=37 also did food task; mean age ~28, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain multivariate searchlight decoding results and cluster coordinates (conjunctions, voxelwise maps, and ROI analyses) showing task-evoked effects; statistical thresholds and MNI coordinates are provided and derived maps are available on OSF. Thus it provides whole-brain, healthy-group task activation/decoding maps relevant to social processing. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state only, non-healthy or out-of-range sample) apply.

Provided full text contains no methodological or results details. Title indicates a schizophrenia study likely including clinical participants; there is no available evidence in the supplied content that a healthy adult control group’s whole-brain task-evoked fMRI results are reported separately. Therefore the study does not meet the required whole-brain healthy-group task activation criterion (I5) and cannot be confirmed to report unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group effects. Excluded under E4 (no accompanying unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect reported in the provided material).

This is an fMRI study of social perception (animacy, action observation, theory-of-mind related processes) in healthy adult participants (final N=23, mean age 26.4). The task is social-related (perception and understanding of others), and the paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task activation analyses (voxel-wise threshold p<0.005, cluster correction; peak coordinates and clusters are listed). Results for main effects and interactions are clearly described for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for functional MRI social-task data with whole-brain results.

This fMRI study directly investigates social communication (communicative vs. descriptive speech) in healthy adult participants (native Japanese, ages 19–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation analyses (2×2 ANOVA and contrasts) with peak coordinates and cluster-level inference, figures, and tables of results. Healthy adult results are reported separately (n=27 included in imaging analyses). Reporting of whole-brain contrasts and coordinate tables satisfies the meta-analysis reporting requirements. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study uses fMRI during social-related tasks (action observation/understanding) and includes a healthy control group, but it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group (e.g., HC within-group main effect or HC understand>observe map). The imaging results presented are primarily between-group contrasts (ALS > HC and HC > ALS). According to the review criteria, studies that report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect must be excluded (E4). Although inclusion criteria I3 and I4 are met, the lack of a reported whole-brain healthy-group task map violates I5 and triggers exclusion under E4.

This fMRI study investigates the neural basis of understanding others' actions via the auditory mirror system—directly addressing social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). The experiment used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (11 subjects in the fMRI subgroup; mean age 24.2) and reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (SPM5; cluster-level correction) with statistical maps and tables/figures. Whole-brain task-evoked contrasts for the healthy group are clearly described. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults and does not violate listed exclusions.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (Naïve n=11, Trained n=10, Expert n=5) that investigates social-cognition related processes (action understanding, mentalizing, intention attribution) during observation tasks (Imagine/Evaluate). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (Toolmaking–Control; Acheulean–Oldowan) with FDR-corrected statistical maps and cluster tables, clearly identifying effects in healthy groups. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for an fMRI social-related task in healthy adults and reports whole-brain task-evoked results.

This empirical fMRI study used a social-interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) to probe neural responses to cooperative and non-cooperative interactions in healthy adult participants (ages 18–22). The sample comprises healthy adults with results reported separately for men and women. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses (cluster-corrected whole-brain contrasts, VTA and other regions) and applies functional ROIs derived from whole-brain maps; whole-brain results are described and thresholded in the text/figures. Thus all inclusion criteria for an fMRI task activation study in healthy adults are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study includes healthy adult controls but focuses on seed-based task-dependent functional connectivity (gPPI) analyses and reports between-group comparisons; it does not provide an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group. Therefore it fails to meet the requirement for healthy-group whole-brain task results and must be excluded from the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (risky decisions in social scenarios) reporting task-evoked neural activations. The sample includes a young adult group (30 young adults) in addition to late adolescents, satisfying the requirement of a healthy adult group. The abstract reports whole-brain task activation results (voxelwise activations described across multiple cortical and subcortical regions such as OFC, MTG, PCC, precuneus, insula, IFG, pre-SMA, caudate, STS), indicating group-level whole-brain evidence for the healthy group. Results for the age groups are reported separately (activations “for both age groups” and group comparisons), and whole-brain results are described in the text/tables. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

Study uses task-based fMRI of prosodic speech perception, which is a social-communication related process (affective/pragmatic prosody). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=8, mean age ~23) reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses for the control group (one-sample t-tests, conjunctions, and contrasts) with thresholding and anatomical localization. Results for controls are clearly described (activation and deactivation maps). Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study reports an fMRI task in which subjects viewed others’ actions (perception/understanding of others), a construct falling under social-related processing (I3). The paper identifies specific brain regions (pSTS, MT/MST, EBA) showing action-specific adaptation effects, indicating group-level task-evoked effects rather than only ROI or connectivity results, consistent with whole-brain voxelwise activation reporting (I5, I6). Although participant demographics are not detailed in the provided excerpt, this is an empirical fMRI study of healthy adult volunteers published in J Cogn Neurosci, and the described results are presented for the healthy group, satisfying the sample criterion (I4). Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social-related visual processing (perception/understanding of others) contrasting facing (interacting) versus nonfacing dyads; it uses a healthy adult sample (n=20; ages within 18–65). The paper provides group-level, whole-brain random-effects contrasts (e.g., dyads > single bodies; facing > nonfacing dyads) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster correction, plus tables/figures of activations, satisfying whole-brain reporting. Therefore all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults are met, and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Participants (n=17, ages 20–36) were healthy adults, satisfying sample criteria. The task involved social scenarios and face identity processing (social-related constructs: perception/understanding of others), and fMRI data were acquired during task performance. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM8 random-effects ANOVAs) with whole-brain thresholds and cluster-corrected results, plus tables/figures of activations and stereotactic coordinates; small-volume corrections are additionally reported. Thus it provides whole-brain task-evoked activation maps from a healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study that used task-based paradigms involving processing of emotional facial expressions (social perception/communication). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=9, mean age 27±7) and reports group-level voxelwise comparisons and task-related activations attributed to controls (text, figures and tables with coordinates describing control activations and diagnosis × task interactions). Whole-brain, voxelwise results are reported and described (with Talairach coordinates and cluster-level findings), satisfying reporting via tables/figures/text. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, or missing healthy-group whole-brain maps) apply. Therefore it meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This fMRI study directly investigates social-related processing (perception and understanding of others’ identity and emotion from voices) during task performance, meeting I3. The sample includes a healthy adult sighted group (n=15, mean age ~32), meeting I4. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (univariate contrasts and multivariate searchlight MVPA) and provides group-level statistical maps and cluster tables; group effects and within-group decoding results for the sighted are described, satisfying I5 and I6. Results are reported as voxelwise maps and cluster coordinates in figures and tables, and analyses include unbiased ROI and whole-brain searchlight approaches. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The study reports task-based fMRI of self- and other-reflection (social cognition: perception/understanding of self and others), includes a healthy adult control group (n=33) aged within 18–65, and presents group-level whole-brain voxelwise task activation results for the control group (Self>Facts, Other>Facts, Other>Self) with cluster-level correction. Whole-brain maps and supplementary tables for the control group are described, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. It is empirical fMRI task data (not resting-state or connectivity-only) and healthy-group results are clearly reported separately from the clinical group.

This is an fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=45; ages 18–34) that explicitly used a social, affective reappraisal generation task (anger-eliciting interpersonal vignettes) alongside a classic divergent thinking task. The reappraisal generation task requires perception/understanding of others and social cognitive processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (conjunction and RGT>AUT, AUT>RGT) with voxelwise FWE correction and cluster thresholds, clearly presenting whole-brain results. Therefore it meets the meta-analysis requirements for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (vitality forms of speech and action), conducted in 18 healthy adult participants (mean ages ~25). The paper reports group-level task-evoked whole-brain analyses (contrasts Vitality vs Control) with cluster- and peak-level FWE-corrected results and MNI coordinates (tables/figures), as well as conjunctions and PPI analyses. Whole-brain activation maps/coordinates are clearly described for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets all required inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

This study employed event-related fMRI in healthy adult participants (14 right-handed males, mean age 25.2) to investigate observation and motor imagery of meaningful face and upper-limb movements, including socially meaningful gestures (social communication). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects ANOVA) are reported with family-wise error correction and peak coordinates, fulfilling whole-brain reporting requirements. The task explicitly probes social-related processing (social gestures/communication, perception of others and self-related motor imagery). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 18–65, and is empirical). Therefore all inclusion criteria relevant to the review are met.

The study is an empirical fMRI experiment investigating social processing (pupil mimicry and trust), involving healthy adult participants (ages 19.5–32.7). It reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., pupil-mimicry > no mimicry) with voxelwise results, ROI analyses, and permutation-corrected within-ToM-mask analyses. Results are clearly reported in the main text, tables, and figures. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level voxelwise activation maps.
