This study meets inclusion criteria: it uses fMRI during a social task (Trust Game) examining social decision-making (I3); the sample is healthy adults aged 19–30 with group-level results reported separately (I4); the paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., GAME>CONTROL, INVESTOR>CONTROL, TRUSTEE>CONTROL) with coordinates and tables (I5); whole-brain results are clearly described in text, figures and table of coordinates (I6). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) apply.

This empirical fMRI study uses a social-related task (social appraisal of faces) and reports task-evoked, whole-brain group-level results. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=21) reported separately and presents whole-brain contrasts, coordinates, figures and corrected cluster results for the control group. Reporting meets acceptable formats (tables/figures) for whole-brain results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, non-adult-only, or non-empirical) are met.

This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (ages 18–35), using task-evoked olfactory self-assessment (‘would you like to smell like this?’) that probes perception/understanding of self, a social-related construct. Group-level, within-group (healthy participants) second-level contrasts were conducted (e.g., ‘self’-peptide minus solvent; ‘self’-peptide minus ‘non-self’-peptide) with activation coordinates reported in MNI space (right middle frontal cortex) and statistical thresholds described. The paper states that whole-brain analysis was performed and presents voxelwise activation coordinates and corrected p-values; results are clearly identified for the healthy group. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state, and participants are within 18–65).

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (mean age 22.9; 15 subjects included) using a social interaction/provocation task (modified Taylor Aggression Paradigm) that probes social processing (reactive aggression, perception/response to others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts with GLMs, statistical maps, coordinate tables and figures (thresholds and cluster sizes provided), and results are clearly from the healthy participant group. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample) apply.

This fMRI study investigates hypnotic suggestion-induced pain and its neural correlates in healthy adults. It includes whole-brain, group-level voxelwise results and reports coordinates (satisfying I4, I5, I6). However, the experimental task is focused on pain induction and modulation via hypnotic suggestion rather than on social-related processing constructs (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception/understanding of self or others). Although verbal suggestion is an interpersonal element, the study’s aims, design, and reported contrasts target sensory and pain-processing systems rather than social cognitive processes. Therefore it does not satisfy the required inclusion criterion I3 (social-related task) and must be excluded.

This fMRI study investigates learning about others’ preferences and social influence on inter-temporal choice, using a social-related task (delegated decisions for novel and familiar others) in healthy adult participants (mean ages 23.6 and 25.6; adults 18–65). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (random-effects second-level analyses, cluster-defining thresholds and FWE correction) with reported coordinates and figures. Results and contrasts for healthy/control participants are clearly described. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none.

The study reports an fMRI task that probes social processing (fearful and calm faces), includes a healthy adult control group (age 18–65) reported separately, and provides group-level whole-brain task-evoked activation results for the control group (within-group maps and stereotaxic coordinates/Z-scores in tables; thresholded whole-brain results described). Whole-brain between- and within-group analyses are reported (not ROI-only), and activation tables/figures clearly describe the control group effects. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social-cognition task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes Task and an age-judgement control), includes a well-characterized healthy adult control group (n≈24, ages 18–59), and presents group-level whole-brain activation results for the healthy controls (described in the text and Supplementary Table S2) using FWE-corrected voxelwise analyses. The methods describe whole-brain preprocessing and inference (voxelwise Z threshold and cluster correction), and the paper explicitly reports healthy-control activation patterns, satisfying the meta-analysis requirements for whole-brain, task-evoked maps. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical paper) are violated.

This article is a narrative review summarizing the authors’ prior fMRI studies rather than an original empirical report presenting new whole-brain, group-level task activation maps for a healthy adult sample. Although it discusses fMRI experiments in healthy adults, the paper itself does not provide original whole-brain statistical maps or clearly reported group-level voxelwise results for a healthy/control adult group. Therefore it meets exclusion criterion E6 (non-empirical review without original fMRI data in healthy adults).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20) that examines social-related processing (imitation-inhibition, self–other distinction, mentalizing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (incongruent > congruent) with stereotactic coordinates and statistical thresholds (e.g., p<0.001) and describes conjunction/meta-analytic analyses. Whole-brain results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented in the text/tables/figures. Therefore it meets the fMRI social-task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This study reports task-based fMRI of gesture-speech integration, a social-communication process. It includes healthy adult participant groups (H-group: n=19, ages 19–32; C-group: n=17) reported separately from clinical participants. The paper presents whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task activation results for the healthy/control group (e.g., conjunction and contrasts with MNI coordinates and significance values; Supplementary Table 2), not just ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Thus it satisfies the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and provides usable whole-brain results.

The task involved listening to human footsteps and reporting motion direction, which constitutes perception of others’ actions (a form of social-related processing: Perception and Understanding of Others). The study used fMRI in healthy adults (10 participants aged 20–29) and reports group-level, whole-brain task activation contrasts (e.g., ‘footstep minus rest’) with random-effects analysis and supplementary maps/tables. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for a social-related fMRI task in healthy adults and provides whole-brain healthy-group results.

This study used task-based fMRI of Theory-of-Mind (visual joke) — a social cognition paradigm (meets I3). It includes a healthy control group of adults (n=13) matched for age and IQ (meets I4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked activation maps and within-group contrasts (ToM vs Physical) with tables/figures and thresholding/cluster correction, including results attributable to the control group (meets I5 and I6). No exclusion criteria are triggered.

The study does not investigate social-related processing: fMRI tasks used are verbal associative fluency and Hayling sentence completion (verbal executive and response-inhibition tasks), which do not probe social communication, affiliation/attachment, or perception/understanding of self/others. Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (mean age ~27) and reports whole-brain, group-level task activation maps for the healthy controls (satisfying I4, I5, I6), it fails to meet inclusion criterion I3 (social-related task). Therefore it must be excluded.

This fMRI study investigates the neural processing of emotional speech prosody (social communication/perception of others) using task-based functional MRI in a sample of healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 24.8). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (emotional > neutral prosody) with cluster-corrected statistics (Table 2; Figures 1–2), alongside ROI analyses. All inclusion criteria are met: (I3) social-related task (prosody/social communication), (I4) healthy adult sample (18–65), (I5) whole-brain group-level voxelwise results clearly reported, and (I6) results presented in text/tables/figures. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, age appropriate, empirical fMRI data).

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=27, mean age 27) that investigates processing of others' facial expressions (social perception/understanding). The task (viewing disgust vs distaste vs neutral faces during gender discrimination) addresses social-related processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., canonical disgust vs neutral; canonical disgust vs distaste) with tables/coordinates and figures, not limited to ROI-only results. Results for the healthy control group are reported separately. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level task-evoked maps (I3, I4, I5, I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

This study used functional MRI during a social-related task (facial emotion recognition from eyes/mouth), includes a healthy adult control group (age ~23.6) with results reported separately, and reports group-level whole-brain task analyses. The paper provides whole-brain within-group contrasts for the control group (NTOXT>PLA) with reported clusters and a table of activations (Table 2), fulfilling the requirement for voxelwise whole-brain healthy-group task effects. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are satisfied.

The study uses task-based fMRI during a social-norm inference task (social-related processing). It includes a healthy adult control group (22 TD males, ages 18–35) with results reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts/maps (e.g., all-stimuli vs fixation, visual and auditory GLM contrasts) for the control group and describes statistical results and voxelwise activations. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although this is a task-based fMRI study of personal (social) familiarity and reports whole-brain, group-level activation maps for the healthy control group, the healthy participants are described as "healthy elderly"/older adults rather than adults in the 18–65 range required by the review. No subgroup of healthy participants aged 18–65 is reported separately. Therefore the study violates the age-range inclusion requirement and must be excluded (E5).

This is an fMRI study that uses a social-related action observation task (observing two hands performing gestures) addressing perception/understanding of others and interaction representation. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=29, ages 18–28). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Observation > Neutral; 2H DIFF > 2H SAME) with voxelwise statistical maps and peak coordinates (Table 1) and whole-brain images, explicitly from the healthy/control group. Results include whole-brain univariate contrasts and PPI analyses; findings are not restricted to ROIs. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social perception (classification of agents’ actions; addresses perception/understanding of others). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=12, mean age 27.3), satisfying the age and healthy-sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (SPM2 random-effects analyses) with FDR-corrected results, cluster tables, coordinates and regression results linking behaviour and BOLD (Tables 1–2, figures), meeting whole-brain reporting requirements. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 and does not violate exclusion criteria (no ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical limitations).

This is an fMRI study of healthy young adults (ages 21–24) that includes a social manipulation (peer observation) during task performance, addressing social-related processing (social influence/mentalizing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation results for both the Go/No-Go and Stoplight tasks (traditional subtraction analyses) and provides thresholded/unthresholded maps in NeuroVault. Although the paper emphasizes seed-based connectivity analyses, it also presents whole-brain activation maps and contrasts for the healthy participant group. Participants are healthy adults within the 18–65 range and results for this group are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study uses task-based fMRI during a social-cognitive visual perspective-taking task (meets I3). It includes a clearly reported healthy adult control group (n=37) with separate behavioral and imaging results (meets I4). The paper presents group-level whole-brain, voxelwise activation maps and contrasts for perspective-taking (e.g., Fig. 2 and accompanying text describing healthy volunteer activation patterns) and reports cluster-corrected voxelwise results, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked healthy-group maps (meets I5). Results are reported in figures/tables and described in text, consistent with acceptable reporting formats (meets I6). No exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study that directly assesses social-related processing (mental state recognition) using the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Task (I3). The sample includes a clearly reported healthy adult control group (age-matched controls) analyzed separately from HD patients (I4). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task activation contrasts (e.g., mental state > age; and group and subgroup second-level factorial models) with FWE-corrected cluster results and tables/figures describing control-group effects (I5,I6). Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met. Confidence is slightly reduced because exact numerical age range for participants (18–65) is not explicitly listed in the provided excerpt, but participants are described as adult age-matched controls, and group-level whole-brain control results are reported separately.

This study used task-based fMRI during a social cognition task (Reading-the-Mind-in-the-Eyes Test), satisfying I3. It included a healthy adult control group (n=18) aged within 18–65 and reports results for that group separately in the analyses, satisfying I4. The Methods state that second-level, group-level one-sample t tests were computed separately for all five groups (emotional/mental state recognition > gender discrimination), indicating a whole-brain, voxelwise group-level task contrast was obtained for the healthy/control group, satisfying I5. Whole-brain results are described in the text and figures/tables (cluster-level PFWE-corrected maps and planned contrasts involving the healthy group), and presentation in figures/tables meets I6. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, only between-group contrasts without healthy-group map, or non-empirical study) apply. Therefore the paper meets all required inclusion criteria for the review objective.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (mentalizing/understanding others via the why/how task and default-mode network activation). Participants were healthy adult humans (n≈27–28, ages 21–33), meeting the age/sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation maps and conjunction analyses, with cluster-extent correction, coordinates, tables and figures (Study 1 whole-brain results and Study 2 ROI + whole-brain confirmation). Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and clearly. It is not an ROI-only, resting-state, nor clinical-only study. Therefore it satisfies the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of fearful vs happy eyes; oxytocin modulation) in healthy adult participants (final N=43 healthy males, mean age ~24), satisfying the sample criterion. The paper reports group-level fMRI analyses focused on ROIs but also reports exploratory whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked results (whole-brain analysis and Supplementary Tables S1–S3) clearly derived from the healthy/control groups. Whole-brain results are described in the text and supplements. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 and does not violate listed exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 18–60) that investigates social-related processing (observation of mouth actions, social communication, empathy). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (SPM analyses, FWE-corrected maps, tables of coordinates and figures) for within-group and between-group contrasts. Thus it satisfies the fMRI social-task criterion, healthy adult sample criterion, and whole-brain reporting requirements.

The study uses task-based fMRI to probe neural mechanisms of persuasion/social processing (celebrity–object pairing), involving social cognition constructs (perception/understanding of others, trust). Participants were healthy adults (young females, mean age 21.8), satisfying sample criteria. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects task activation analyses with thresholding and cluster correction and lists significant activation clusters in tables and figures (i.e., whole-brain voxelwise results from the healthy group). Behavioral and imaging results are clearly described for the healthy participant group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This empirical fMRI study used a social-related task (anticipation of touching an animate versus inanimate target), recruiting healthy adult participants aged 21–33, and reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (paired-sample t-tests and covariate analyses) with FDR-corrected results and coordinates/figures. Resting-state analyses are present but are accompanied by whole-brain task results. Thus it satisfies all inclusion criteria (I3, I4, I5, I6) and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of perception of others’ emotions (dynamic audio–visual emotional cues), which falls within social-related processing. The samples are healthy adults (Study 1 mean age 22.3, Study 2 mean age 20.6; ranges 18–33 and 18–23). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation results (whole-brain analyses with tables of peak coordinates, figures, and statistical thresholds) clearly identified for the healthy participant groups. Thus it satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (male, ages 18–30) performing a social interpersonal-distance task (affiliation/personal space). Whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses are reported (FDR-corrected results, main effects and treatment×protagonist interaction) with regions listed and follow-up ROI analyses. Thus it meets the fMRI social-task requirement, healthy adult sample, and provides whole-brain task activation results described in the text/tables. No exclusion criteria are violated.

The study sample comprises children and adolescents (ages 8–19; mean 14), and no separate healthy adult (18–65) group is recruited or reported. Although it uses task-based fMRI of social-related processing (vocal emotion recognition) and reports whole-brain group-level activation maps for the youth sample, it does not satisfy the requirement to include a healthy adult group analyzed separately. Therefore it fails the age-related inclusion requirement and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social evaluation (perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (N=20, ages 18–29). The task is social (forced-choice judgments about target persons across situations) and uses task-evoked BOLD fMRI. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (multilevel whole-brain MLM, cluster coordinates and figures; supplementary tables reported) and ROI follow-ups, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, participants are within 18–65, and the paper is empirical). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=16, ages ~21) that used a social-related task (judgments of pride, a self-conscious emotion involving theory-of-mind/social cognition) during scanning. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise contrasts (pride minus neutral, joy minus neutral, pride minus joy) with coordinate tables and statistical thresholds and regression analyses linking ratings to activations. Whole-brain results are clearly reported in tables/figures. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, includes healthy adults within 18–65). Therefore it meets I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an fMRI study that investigates naturalistic theory-of-mind/social cognition using a video-based task (ToM vs physical inference). It reports results for a healthy adult control group (n=22; analyses reported for the control group separately) within the adult age range (18–65). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (ToM > physical inference) with family-wise error cluster-corrected activations and tables of coordinates for the mentalising network in the control group (see Table 3 and figures). Whole-brain within-group task-evoked maps for the healthy/control group are clearly described. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 and does not violate exclusion criteria (no ROI-only, resting-state, or non-empirical-only reporting).

Full text not accessible and available information (title and citation) indicates a study of first-episode schizophrenia. There is no evidence in the provided content that (1) a healthy adult control group (age 18–65) is included and reported separately, or (2) that the paper reports at least one whole-brain, group-level task activation map for a healthy/control group. Because these required inclusion criteria (I4 and I5) cannot be confirmed from the supplied information, the study must be excluded. The most relevant exclusion criterion is E4 (no accompanying unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect reported or cannot be confirmed).

The study uses fMRI during a social-related emotional face matching task and includes a healthy adult control group (ages 21–64). However, it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The paper reports whole-brain group×drug interactions and a task activation map collapsed across group and drug (Supplementary Fig. S2), but no standalone voxelwise healthy-group task map or within-control main effect map is presented. Therefore it fails inclusion criterion I5 and meets exclusion criterion E4 (reports only between-group contrasts/interactions without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=7, ages 20–35) that used whole-brain fMRI while participants read sentences describing events and states. Many stimuli involved social content and the authors explicitly identify a large-scale semantic factor interpreted as people/social interactions and report associated voxelwise brain clusters (Figure 4A and Supporting Information Table S3). The study reports group-level, whole-brain analyses (factor analysis of voxel activation profiles and identification of factor-related clusters) and provides voxelwise/cluster results and supporting tables. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for an fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked evidence.

This empirical fMRI study used a face-localizer task (faces vs objects/textures) that targets social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy adult sample (n=51, ages 18–42) reported separately from children. Group-level whole-brain task activation maps for adults were computed and reported (mixed-effects FLAME group maps, contrasts such as Face>Object and Face>Texture, with thresholding and figures/tables). Thus the paper provides whole-brain task-evoked results for healthy adults and meets the review's reporting requirements.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers using an incidental facial-emotion (gender discrimination) task, which targets social perception/processing. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., fearful vs. neutral; whole-brain comparisons reported at p<.001 uncorrected and supplementary tables) and presents activation maps and coordinates for the healthy subject groups. Participants were screened for psychiatric disorders and analyzed as healthy adult groups. Therefore it satisfies requirements for an fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level results.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social processing (monitoring others' decisions) in healthy adult participants (N=12, mean age 21). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise second-level SPM analyses with reported statistical maps/coordinates (e.g., peak coordinates and SPM{F} results) and describes correction procedures (small volume correction) for the ACC. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for an fMRI social task in healthy adults and provides whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (reported in text and figures/tables).

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (face perception/recognition) with healthy adult participants (ages 19–36). The authors report group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects GLM, cluster correction) and provide Talairach coordinates for significant activations (right precentral and right cingulate gyri), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. Results are reported in text/figures with coordinates. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical paper) apply. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group and uses task-based fMRI examining self-related (agency) processing (relevant to social-related constructs), it does not provide a usable whole-brain, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group. The authors report ROI analyses showing activation in frontal ROIs for controls, but whole-brain analyses yielded no significant activations and no whole-brain coordinates or maps for the healthy group are reported. Therefore the paper effectively reports only ROI-based results (and between-group ROI contrasts) without an accompanying unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect, failing the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI with healthy control participants and examines socially relevant emotion-word processing, the paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The reported whole-brain results are primarily pooled across all participants or presented as between-group contrasts (controls > ASC) and ROI analyses. Per the review criteria, studies that present only between-group contrasts without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect must be excluded (E4). Therefore this study is excluded for failing to provide a standalone healthy-group whole-brain task map.

This empirical fMRI study examines neural responses to faces and specifically manipulates changeable aspects of faces (gaze, head view, expression), which are social-communication relevant. Participants are healthy adult observers (n=8). The paper reports group-level voxelwise analyses (Z statistic images, Talairach coordinates, and whole-brain contrasts such as faces vs objects) and tables/figures of the resulting activation maps, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Thus it meets the review’s social-related task definition, includes healthy adult participants, and provides whole-brain task-evoked results (coordinates/figures).

While this is an fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind) that includes a healthy adult control group, the paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. The primary analyses use group ICA across all participants to derive task-correlated components and report combined-sample component maps and between-group (ASD vs control) contrasts. There is no clearly identified whole-brain healthy-group task effect (control-only map) presented. Therefore it violates the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task map and is excluded.

This is an fMRI study of pain empathy (a social-related process: perception/understanding of others/self) that includes a separately reported healthy adult control group (n=21; ages 18–60). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation analyses for the healthy/control group (e.g., Self minus Other and Other minus Self contrasts; thresholding and extent criteria described; supplementary Table S1 and figures provided), not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social group processing in healthy adult participants (meets I3 and I4). However, the main analyses report region-of-interest/atlas-based intersubject correlation results (averaging voxels within 55 Harvard–Oxford regions and ROI analyses for visual/category-selective areas). The paper does not report a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-activation statistical map for the healthy group (no unmasked voxelwise maps or contrasts are presented); results are reported at the regional/ROI level. Therefore it fails inclusion criterion I5 and meets exclusion criterion E2 (ROI-only analyses with no whole-brain voxelwise results).

The paper reports fMRI during clearly social-related tasks (theory of mind ‘Reading the Mind in the Eyes’ and basic emotion tasks) and includes a healthy adult control group reported separately (n=14). The authors conducted and report group-level, whole-brain regression analyses for each group (controls, patients, siblings) with thresholding and report activated regions as well as MNI coordinates and laterality indices. Whole-brain results for the healthy/control group are described in the text (and in tables/coordinates), satisfying the requirement for unmasked, group-level task-evoked maps. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only or connectivity-only reporting) apply.

Although the study used task-based fMRI of social processing (script-driven interpersonal rejection and imagined aggression) and included a healthy adult control group (female adults 18–65), the paper reports whole-brain functional connectivity analyses and group differences in connectivity rather than presenting any group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation maps for the healthy/control group. The standard activation results were noted as reported in prior work, but this full text does not provide unmasked healthy-group whole-brain task effects (voxelwise maps or coordinate tables) required by the review. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked healthy-group results and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study using a social-cognitive task (neutral face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM) in healthy adult participants (N=74), meeting the review’s target population. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task analyses (one-sample t-tests and ANOVA across participants) with whole-brain significance thresholds and results described in text, figures and supplementary tables, not limited to ROI-only findings. Although ROI analyses were also performed, whole-brain task-evoked activations for the healthy/control group are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, out-of-range ages, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-interaction task (virtual handshake inducing social acceptance vs rejection), directly assessing social processing/mentalizing. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=16, mean age 27.4) with results reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts for the control group (refusal vs acceptance) using AFNI and presents coordinate tables and corrected cluster-level results. Reporting includes tables/figures of the healthy-group activation maps. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, includes within-group healthy task effects, participants are within 18–65, and it is empirical). Therefore it satisfies I3, I4, I5, and I6.

While this fMRI study examines social gaze processing and includes a healthy adult control group, it does not provide a clearly identified, unmasked whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the healthy/control group. The reported group results focus on group × gaze-direction interactions and ROI-based small-volume corrected effects within a priori ToM regions; the within-group healthy/control effects are presented in the context of ROI analyses or interactions rather than as an unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task map. Whole-brain peaks cited for motor/visual networks appear to be from contrasts across subjects and are not clearly reported as a standalone healthy-group whole-brain activation map. Therefore the paper matches exclusion criterion E4 (between-group contrasts/interactions without an accompanying unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

This study reports task-based fMRI during an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma, a social interaction task probing cooperation/defection (meets social-related construct). The sample consists of 30 healthy adult participants (mean age 21.2), satisfying the healthy adult sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain (random-effects and voxelwise) task activation analyses (e.g., contrasts for choice and outcome epochs) with statistical thresholds and figures/tables, fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Whole-brain results are presented for the healthy participant group (not limited to a narrow subgroup). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (I3, I4, I5, I6).

The study meets several inclusion points (fMRI social task; healthy adult control group present) but does not report an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task activation map or within-group main effect for the control group. The reported whole-brain results are group-by-empathy interaction and between-group differences; no clear voxelwise healthy-control task map (main effect or within-group contrast) is provided in the text. This falls under exclusion criterion E4 (only between-group/interactions reported without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

This study used task-based fMRI (Cyberball social exclusion), includes a healthy adult control group (HC; n=28) reported separately, and reports whole-brain, group-level task-evoked results for the healthy controls (one-way ANOVA main effect of condition in HC) with voxelwise FWE-corrected maps and coordinates/figures. The task probes social exclusion (a social-related construct). Healthy participants are adults (female-only sample) and results for the HC group are clearly described. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 are satisfied.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (U.S. and Korean samples, ages ~20), using social-related persuasion tasks probing mentalizing/social cognition. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (persuasive vs unpersuasive) are reported with coordinates and tables (thresholds and extent reported), and results are described for the healthy/control groups. Reporting includes tables of coordinates and figures. Thus it meets the review's criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults with whole-brain group results.

Although this study uses task-based fMRI of a social attribution task (meets I3) and includes a healthy adult control group (meets I4), the imaging results are reported primarily as between-group contrasts (patient vs control) and ROI-extracted % signal changes. The paper does not provide an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task activation map or clearly described whole-brain, voxelwise within-group statistical maps for the healthy/control group. This matches exclusion criterion E4 (only between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect). Therefore it cannot be included for a meta-analysis requiring healthy-group whole-brain maps.

This fMRI study investigates face perception and social/emotional processing (mentalizing, eye-region attention) using the Thatcher Illusion, a social-related task. It includes a healthy adult control group (NT; n=18, mean age 25.8±5.3) reported separately from the ASD group. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts for the NT group (within-group whole-brain activation maps, thresholded and described in text/figures/tables). Therefore it meets the meta-analysis requirements for fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain healthy-group results.

This is an empirical fMRI study of action imitation/observation, a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (N=16) reported separately from the schizophrenia group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation contrasts for the healthy group (within-group contrasts and peak Talairach coordinates are provided in Table 2 and described in the text), with cluster-level correction for multiple comparisons. Results for healthy subjects’ activation maps (e.g., imitation > nonimitative action; animated > nonanimated observation) are clearly reported, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain evidence. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the review.

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social joint-attention paradigm (face-to-face interaction), includes at least one healthy adult control group (matched NT and an independent ROI control group; ages within 18–65), and presents group-level whole-brain voxelwise activation contrasts for the neurotypical/control groups (e.g., RJA vs SA, IJA vs SA) with coordinates and cluster thresholds. Results for healthy/control groups are clearly reported. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

The study does not report task-evoked, whole-brain fMRI results from a social-related task in healthy adults. It uses a behavioral theory-of-mind task (Short Story Task) outside the scanner and reports resting-state fMRI graph metrics (global efficiency) in CHR and healthy volunteer groups (ages 12–24). No whole-brain, task-evoked voxelwise activation maps for a healthy adult task condition are provided. Therefore it fails the review's requirement for task-based whole-brain activation and is excluded under E3 (studies reporting only resting-state/seed-based/effective connectivity without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map).

The study uses fMRI during a social-related task and includes a healthy adult control group, but it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group. The reported whole-brain results (Table 2) and primary statistical maps are between-group contrasts (controls > cocaine users) and SVC/ROI-corrected analyses; no standalone healthy-group whole-brain task effect (main effect or within-group contrast) is clearly provided. This violates inclusion criterion I5 and meets exclusion criterion E4 (reporting only between-group contrasts without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect). Therefore the study cannot be included for the meta-analysis focused on healthy-group whole-brain activations.

This peer-reviewed fMRI study directly investigates social-related processing (perception and interpretation of others’ emotions via dynamic facial expressions) using task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (mean ages ~25–26). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects voxelwise analyses and provides coordinates/tables/figures for whole-brain contrasts (dynamic > static, and face conditions > baseline). Results for healthy adult groups are reported separately. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (self/other understanding in romantic relationships) in healthy adults. Sample: N=42 healthy adults, ages 23–40, within the 18–65 range. The study reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., self>other, positive>neutral) with family-wise error (FWE) correction at the voxel level and cluster thresholds, and presents tables/figures of activation results. The task is explicitly social (affiliation/attachment, perception/understanding of self and others). Thus all required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study does not meet the review inclusion criteria. The task is a non-social visual attention task (not a social-related processing task), so I3 is not satisfied. The sample comprises boys/children and adolescent sibs (not healthy adults aged 18–65), and no healthy adult group is reported separately, so I4 is not satisfied; this violates exclusion criterion E5 (participants outside the 18–65 adult range). Although whole-brain task activation maps are reported, they pertain to child/adolescent groups rather than healthy adults. Therefore the study must be excluded from a meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This study used task-based fMRI examining mothers viewing videos of their own infant vs strangers—addressing affiliation/attachment (a social-related construct). Participants were healthy adult mothers (ages 22–37), screened for depression/anxiety with exclusions reported and healthy-group results presented (final N=23). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts (own infant > stranger infant) with statistical maps and tables, and describes voxelwise whole-brain and connectivity analyses. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level task-evoked results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, age out-of-range) apply.

While the study uses fMRI of social-related face processing (meets I3) and includes healthy adult participants (meets I4), it does not provide a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. The primary whole-brain genome-wide analyses combined healthy controls and psychiatric participants, and although the authors report no effect of diagnosis and perform covariate analyses, they do not present an unambiguous healthy-group whole-brain activation map. The independent replication used an ROI approach in healthy volunteers rather than whole-brain healthy-group maps. Therefore the paper fails inclusion criterion I5 and must be excluded under E4.

This is an original fMRI study examining perception/understanding of others’ actions (mirror-system responses to action sounds and pantomime), which falls under social-related processing. It includes healthy adult groups (sighted and congenitally blind; ages within 18–65 range reported), reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts with cluster correction and maps/tables, and presents within-group (healthy) activation results. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not non-empirical).

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of empathic/social processing and includes healthy control participants (including adults), the paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The reported imaging results focus on group-by-age interactions and between-group differences in covariation with age; within-group whole-brain healthy-control task effects are not reported (results are reported as group-difference maps, ROI-based correlations, and extracted peak correlations). This violates exclusion criterion E4 (only between-group contrasts/interactions without an accompanying unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect). Therefore the study must be excluded from the meta-analysis.

Although this is an fMRI study of emotion processing (a social-cognition-related task) with healthy adult control participants, the paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The main whole-brain effects are reported across all subjects and the reported results focus on between-group contrasts (siblings vs controls) and ROI analyses. Therefore it fails to meet inclusion criterion I5 and meets exclusion criterion E4 (only between-group contrasts without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task effect).

This is an fMRI study addressing social-related processing (animacy perception and social inference) using task-based functional MRI. The sample comprises 15 healthy adult participants (mean age 26.6), satisfying the age and healthy-sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses with voxelwise statistical maps and coordinates (tables and figures), and describes thresholding and cluster-level results—meeting the whole-brain reporting criterion. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range participants) apply. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (parents aged 22–37) using socially relevant, attachment-related stimuli (own-infant vs. standard-infant videos). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses are reported (second-level GLM, whole-brain intersubject correlations, cluster locations, thresholds, and ROI follow-up), with results clearly identified for the healthy adult group. Although the sample is modest (n=30) and some analyses are exploratory with liberal thresholds, all required inclusion criteria are met: fMRI social task (I3), healthy adult sample 18–65 (I4), and whole-brain group-level task-evoked maps reported (I5, I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study examining memory retrieval of emotionally valent sporting events in college fans, which probes social-cognitive processes (self-referential processing, perspective-taking, social cognition). Participants were healthy adult males (mean ages ~20–22). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (SPM5 random-effects results, tables and figures) and also provides coordinate tables and figures for activation maps. Thus it satisfies the meta-analysis requirements for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although the study includes a social-related fMRI task (facial expression discrimination) and a healthy adult control group (I3 and I4 met), the paper reports task results primarily as between-group contrasts (patients > healthy controls) and does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group alone. The task findings shown (e.g., Fig. 1b and Table 1) focus on patient hyperactivation relative to controls rather than a within-group healthy activation map. Therefore the study fails the requirement for reporting a healthy-group whole-brain task effect and meets exclusion criterion E4 (reports only between-group contrasts without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect). Note: the paper also emphasizes resting-state and seed-based connectivity analyses, which do not compensate for the missing healthy-group whole-brain task map.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (Experiments 1 and 2; N=20 each, ages 19–32), investigating perception of social actions. Whole-brain group-level voxelwise analyses (searchlight RSA and cluster-corrected statistical maps) are reported with coordinates and tables, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results. The study addresses social-related processing (perception/interpretation of others’ actions). Results and maps are presented in figures/tables and described in text, and data are available. Therefore inclusion criteria for social-task fMRI in healthy adults and provision of whole-brain results are met.

The study is an fMRI experiment on perception of others’ vocal emotions (social communication), meeting the social-related task requirement. Participants were healthy adults (N=22; age 19–36), meeting the sample criterion. The paper reports a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (voice localizer: [vocal > non-vocal]) used to define the TVA, providing whole-brain voxelwise activation maps from the healthy group. Whole-brain results are presented and described in the text/figures; although many main contrasts used ROI/SVC, the presence of the localizer whole-brain map satisfies the whole-brain evidence criterion. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

This fMRI study investigates perception of emotional facial expressions (a social communication/social perception task) and therefore addresses the review objective. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=19; ages 18–51) reported separately from the clinical Tourette group. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task results: patient and control t-maps/contrasts are described (e.g., control t-maps showing activations for fearful and neutral faces; between-group and patient within-group whole-brain contrasts are reported with FWE-corrected tables). Although the primary emphasis is on patients, the manuscript clearly identifies and describes control-group whole-brain task effects (textual t-map descriptions and contrasts), satisfying reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria appear violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, includes healthy adults, empirical fMRI data). Therefore the study should be included.

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social interaction (multiround trust game), includes a healthy adult control group (n=21; ages 18–47), and presents whole-brain group-level task activation maps for the healthy group (Figure 2A; voxelwise PFWE < 0.05). Whole-brain second-level analyses and healthy-group maps are explicitly described and visualized, satisfying requirements for reporting unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effects. There is no indication of exclusion criteria being violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, includes healthy adults in range, and is empirical). Therefore the paper meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This study used fMRI during a social-related task (viewing socio-emotional film scenes that evoke interpersonal conflict) and explicitly examines social cognition and valence prioritization, satisfying the review objective. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=25 analyzed; ages reported, right-handed, screened for psychiatric/neurological history), meeting the age and healthy-sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (mixed-effects group regressions with voxelwise z>2.3 and cluster correction; conjunction and PPI analyses), and results are presented as whole-brain maps and tables/figures. Whole-brain results from the healthy/control group are clearly described. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range age) are violated. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 and should be included in the meta-analysis.

This study uses task-based fMRI of emotional face processing, a social-perception task (meets I3). The sample comprises healthy adult participants aged 18–30 with results reported for the healthy group (meets I4). The paper reports group-level faces>ovals task activation analyses, ROI and exploratory whole-brain analyses (including unmasked whole-brain and tables/figures; meets I5 and I6). Although additional connectivity (PPI) analyses are included, the paper also provides task-evoked whole-brain activation maps for the healthy sample, so no exclusion criteria are triggered. Therefore the study meets all required inclusion criteria for the review objective.

The study uses fMRI during a social-related task (implicit facial emotion processing of fearful vs neutral faces), includes a separate healthy adult control group (24 controls, ages within 18–65) and reports group-level whole-brain analyses. The authors explicitly derived a control-group peak within an anatomically defined amygdala mask (MNI coordinate −26,0,−20) and generated whole-brain contrast images (fear vs neutral) used in connectivity analyses. Whole-brain GLM and group random-effects analyses are described; qualifying control-group results are reported as coordinates and used for seed localization. Although the primary reported PPI findings are between-group, the paper provides a clearly identified healthy-group, whole-brain task effect (control amygdala peak) and satisfies the allowance for whole-brain results reported as coordinates/figures. Therefore inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using an explicit facial emotion identification task (social perception of others' emotions), meeting the social-related task requirement. The paper reports results for a healthy adult control group (n=22) separately from the MDD group. Whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked maps for the ‘faces minus animals’ contrast are presented for the HC group (one-sample t tests) and reported with coordinates in tables/supplementary materials and illustrated in figures. Thus the manuscript provides whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps (not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Participants are adults within the 18–65 range. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 are satisfied.

The study uses task-based fMRI of gesture pantomime, a social communication task (social action planning). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=25) and reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses with within-group (control) results noted (within-group results and tables/figures provided in supplementary material). Analyses used SPM8 whole-brain contrasts and report thresholds and cluster sizes, satisfying requirements for group-level whole-brain maps for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, no healthy group whole-brain map, or out-of-range ages) appear to apply.

The study uses fMRI during a social-related cognitive empathy task and includes a healthy adult control group (satisfies I3 and I4). However, the imaging results are reported primarily as between-group whole-brain contrasts (schizophrenia vs controls) and clusters derived from these between-group differences; the paper does not present an unmasked, voxelwise whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group (no within-group/control main-effect whole-brain map is reported). Therefore it fails I5 and violates exclusion criterion E4 (reports only between-group contrasts without an accompanying unmasked healthy-group whole-brain task effect).

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social-related task (imaginary sentence completion about mother/father), addressing affiliation/attachment and social processing. It includes a healthy adult group (n=15, mean age ~28) reported separately from a clinical schizophrenia group. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation results for the healthy/control group (one-sample t-tests and coordinates reported in Table 2 and text). Whole-brain results are reported in tables/figures (satisfying reporting requirements). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, absence of healthy-group whole-brain map, or out-of-range ages) are met. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=21 males, ages 21–39) performing a social-related task (negative vs positive social feedback). It uses whole-brain, group-level random-effects analyses (second-level contrasts and corrected cluster thresholds) with results reported in tables/figures and coordinates. The healthy control group results are clearly described and presented. The study therefore meets inclusion criteria for an fMRI social processing study in healthy adults and provides whole-brain task-evoked maps (reported in text, tables, and figures). No exclusion criteria are met.

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social interaction paradigm (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma), with healthy adult participants (ages 18–22). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain task activation contrasts (e.g., CC vs CD; contrasts comparing human vs computer partners and drug vs placebo) with corrected cluster-level inference and supplementary tables/figures, not limited to ROI analyses. Healthy-control group results are reported separately and compared across sexes. The methods and results therefore satisfy the review’s requirements for fMRI social processing in healthy adults and provision of whole-brain, group-level maps/results.

The study uses fMRI during a social (joint attention) task with healthy adult participants (meets I3 and I4). However, it does not report any group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy group. The paper focuses on ROI-based hyperscanning directed functional connectivity analyses (4-region networks, predefined cortical masks) and probabilistic counts of regional occurrences rather than univariate whole-brain activation results. Therefore it violates inclusion criterion I5 and meets exclusion criteria for studies that present only ROI/connectivity analyses without a whole-brain healthy-group task map.

This is a task-based fMRI study of eye-gaze perception (a social-processing construct) in a sample of healthy adults (ages 18–30). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level second-level analyses (voxelwise SPM-t maps) testing contrasts (variable vs. constant gaze/heads/eyes-only) with AQ as a regressor, thresholded with whole-brain FDR and confirmed in ROI SVC — and coordinates of significant clusters are reported. Thus it meets social-task fMRI (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), whole-brain group-level task-evoked maps clearly from the healthy group (I5), and reporting of whole-brain results via coordinates/tables (I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

This fMRI study examines perception and understanding of others via emotion recognition from dynamic avatars (a social-related task). It tested healthy adult participants (N=19, mean age 28±4.5, all within 18–65) and reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task activation maps (random-effects GLM contrasts, corrected maps shown in figures and described in text, plus parametric whole-brain GLM). Results for the healthy/control group are presented clearly (multiple whole-brain contrasts and ROI analyses derived from those maps). Therefore it satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults and provides whole-brain evidence (figures and coordinate-based descriptions).

This study does not report original, within-study task-evoked whole-brain fMRI results in the healthy adult sample. It uses resting-state fMRI in 20 healthy adults and meta-analytic coactivation (MACM) from the BrainMap database to infer task-related coactivation, but it does not present group-level whole-brain task activation maps from a social (or any) task performed by the included participants. Therefore it fails key inclusion criteria requiring task fMRI whole-brain results (I3, I5). The sample is healthy adults (I4 met), but exclusion criterion E3 applies because the paper reports resting-state and meta-analytic connectivity rather than healthy-group task activation maps.

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social-related task (rapid fearful face processing), includes a healthy adult control group (n=25) with results reported separately, and presents group-level whole-brain analyses (see Appendix Fig S1 and Supplementary Table 1) identifying significant clusters for the control group. The paper therefore satisfies I3 (social-related fMRI task), I4 (healthy adult sample reported separately), I5 (group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps for controls), and I6 (whole-brain results described in text and supplementary materials). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This study used task-based fMRI during a social-related task (fearful face processing) and includes a healthy adult control group (N=13, ages 18–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise within-group activation maps for the control group (main effect of faces; linear contrasts), with coordinates and figures and a whole-brain GLM (global threshold p<0.001 uncorrected) and small-volume corrections reported for ROIs. Results for the healthy/control group are presented separately (within-group analyses and contrasts), satisfying reporting of whole-brain task-evoked effects. Therefore it meets all required inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults that examines memory for real-life social interactions (oral examination enacted by an actor) and the perception/understanding of the bodily self during those events. fMRI was used during repeated retrieval of those socially encoded life events, and group-level whole-brain task-evoked activations are reported (e.g., retrosplenial cortex, medial prefrontal cortex, hippocampus) with tables/figures and corrected statistics. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (within 18–65). The paper therefore meets the criteria for (I3) fMRI during a social-related task (social interaction and self-perception), (I4) healthy adult sample, (I5) reporting of group-level whole-brain task activation maps, and (I6) whole-brain results presented in tables/figures/text. No exclusion criteria are met.

This article investigates oxytocin effects on processing socially relevant cues using fMRI in healthy adults (so I3 and I4 are met). However, the provided full-text metadata does not include any description or evidence of group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy/control group. The title and keywords emphasize the ventral tegmental area (a specific region), suggesting a region-focused analysis; no whole-brain results are shown in the supplied content. Because I cannot verify that whole-brain, voxelwise healthy-group activation maps are reported, the study must be excluded under E2 (only ROI/no whole-brain results).

The study includes healthy adult control participants and uses task fMRI of social-related processing, but it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. Most whole-brain activation results are reported as combined-group effects or as between-group (TD vs ASD) contrasts; the paper relies on between-group contrasts and ROI analyses for group-specific effects rather than providing a standalone whole-brain healthy-group task map. This violates the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map (I5) and thus meets exclusion criterion E4.

This study used resting-state fMRI (Rs-fMRI) and independent component/connectivity analyses rather than any task-based fMRI paradigm probing social-related processing. The meta-analysis requires task-evoked whole-brain activation maps from healthy adult participants. No task-based healthy-group whole-brain results are reported; only resting-state between-group connectivity comparisons (ASD vs TD). Therefore it meets exclusion criterion E3 (resting-state analyses only) and does not satisfy I3 or I5.

This study used resting-state fMRI with a social-evaluation manipulation (critical remarks) and reports seed-based functional connectivity contrasts (criticism > standard) and clustering results. Although the sample consists of healthy adults (age 18–27) and the paradigm involves social-related processing, the paper does not report any group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked activation maps from a standard task analysis. Results are limited to seed-based connectivity and resting-state contrasts. Therefore it meets exclusion criterion E3 (studies reporting only seed-based connectivity/resting-state analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map).

This is an fMRI study of facial emotion discrimination (social perception/understanding of others), meeting the social-related task requirement. The sample includes a group of healthy adult control participants (n=12) reported separately and matched to the high-risk group. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (emotions vs baseline and emotion>neutral) and presents within-group contrasts for controls (e.g., sad > neutral shown for controls) and conjunction/interaction whole-brain analyses with coordinates and figures. Whole-brain results are reported in text, tables/figures, and coordinates. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of infant cries and faces—attachment/affiliation and social perception) in healthy adult participants. The sample consists of 17 healthy nulliparous women aged 19–29. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked contrasts (e.g., cry vs. pink noise; happy vs. neutral faces) with cluster- and FWE-correction and provides coordinate tables/figures and whole-brain correlation analyses. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study includes an fMRI task of social cognition (RMET) and reports whole-brain group-level healthy-control activation maps; however the healthy sample consists of older adults aged 51–84 (mean 68.4) and includes participants >65 with no separate analysis restricted to ages 18–65. This violates the meta-analysis age eligibility. Therefore the study must be excluded under E5 (age criterion).

The study reports an fMRI task probing self-referential processing and perspective-taking (social-related constructs: perception and understanding of self/others), includes a healthy control group of adults, and presents voxelwise, whole-brain task activation results for the healthy control group (within-group contrasts and tables/figures of coordinates). Whole-brain contrasts for self>other and 3PP>1PP within healthy controls are reported and described. Reporting meets acceptable formats (tables/figures/supplement). Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study reports an fMRI experiment using a theory-of-mind (social cognition) task (ToM vs control), satisfying the social-related task requirement. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=109) with no history of schizophrenia or affective disorder, meeting the healthy adult sample criterion. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and statistical contrasts (ToM>control) for the healthy group, with whole-brain corrected results (FWE/FDR) and coordinate tables/figures. Whole-brain results are clearly described in the text and figures. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

This study used task-based fMRI during an implicit emotional face task (angry vs neutral faces), which is a social-perception/understanding-of-others paradigm. A healthy adult control group (ages reported within 18–65, n=23 for the fMRI cohort) is analyzed separately. The methods describe voxelwise, whole-brain second-level GLM analyses (first-level contrasts entered into second-level analyses) and report task-activated brain regions (with further details in the supplementary material), meeting the requirement for a group-level whole-brain task-evoked map for controls. Connectivity (PPI) was also performed but the paper includes whole-brain activation analyses rather than only ROI/seed analyses. Therefore the paper meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of face processing (a social perception task) in healthy adult participants (meets I3 and I4), it does not report any group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy/control group. Analyses are ROI-based interregional correlations and structural covariance rather than whole-brain voxelwise activation results. Therefore it violates the requirement for whole-brain task evidence (I5) and falls under exclusion criterion E2 (reports only ROI/region-based analyses with no whole-brain results).

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-emotional approach-avoidance task (social-related processing) in a sample of healthy adults (N=279, age 18–43). The paper reports group-level task-evoked analyses, including whole-brain contrasts (congruency effects and stress-response-related whole-brain results) and clearly describes these as coming from the healthy/control group. Results are reported with whole-brain correction and ROI SVC, and coordinate/cluster-level findings are provided. All inclusion criteria for the review (task is social-related fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level task maps reported) are satisfied. No exclusion criteria apply.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of a social interaction (joint attention) and includes a healthy adult control group, the manuscript’s primary reported results are cross-brain coupling (connectivity/ICA-based) and between-group comparisons. The full text does not present a clear, unmasked whole-brain, group-level task-evoked activation map (INT>NoINT) explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (only group contrasts and null group differences are described). Therefore it fails the requirement for reporting a healthy-group whole-brain task activation (I5) and meets exclusion criterion E4 (reporting only between-group contrasts/interaction without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social cognition and includes a healthy adult control group, the full text (as provided) reports group comparisons (typically developing vs ASD) and ROI/contrast results (ASD < TD) but does not present or report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. The methods mention one-sample t-tests, but the published results only describe between-group contrasts and ROI analyses derived from those contrasts. Therefore this paper appears to lack the required healthy-group whole-brain task map (violation of E4).
